description:
Bliss! Best place to bring a girlfriend to celebrate a birthday or your mother or your little for her first grown up tea party.

I crave lovejoy's chocolate chip team!
author: Friea B.

description:
Hosted my belated birthday party brunch here! The process was super smooth and I made reservations ahead of time to accommodate a larger party. Gina was the one emailing me back and forth and though I was somewhat unresponsive (I'm sorry!) due to not getting voicemails in time and just being bad at responding to emails because work was busy.. she was still very helpful and friendly! 

We chose the high tea package option and we were able to pick different teas during our brunch. Nobody got too creative and I think we only ordered the white tea in addition to what was already on the table (this was good though!) but Gina also brought us out a pumpkin tea. 

Finger sandwiches were decent but nothing too extraordinary but I think you are mostly paying for the ambiance anyway. The scones were really good though! At the end of our brunch we found the hat rack and decided to snap some photos. I think it's a cute tough to have these out for everyone to borrow and feel a little tea-ready! Overall, cute place and I would be back if I had another event to attend!
author: Emily C.

description:
Do you remember ever having a tea party with your stuff animals or barbie dolls? I do and I remember wanting to live a Barbies life. 

Well here, you can live the dream. I was overwhelmed with disbelief when a friend posted her tea party celebration on Snapchat. I never knew there was such a thing for common people to do. I've only heard of queen and princesses having tea parties. 

I made sure to make reservations because from the yelp reviews, some were saying that it will get busy. And they were right. People are waiting outside before the place even opened. When I walked in is was like walking into a Barbie dream house. Lol It had a homie feel to it, i was seated on a nice comfortable fluffy chair with a sign that said royalty. So you known it was time to take pictures.

They have all kinds of different teas and sandwiches it was hard to decide! My friend and I decided to go with the queens tea for two and boy did it not disappoint. It looked like a meal fit for a queen.  We had so much fun at this adult tea party I couldn't even believe how much fun it actually was to do childhood things again. 

It was a great experience. I'm looking forward to coming back and doing another tea party
author: Monee C.

description:
I've had the pleasure of enjoying high tea service at Lovejoy's Tea Room a few times now, and each time I've been impressed with the quantity and quality of food and tea you receive for an affordable price! 

For $30, you can get the Queen's service, which comes with bottomless tea, two full sandwiches of your choosing, a scone with lemon curd, clotted cream, and raspberry jam, petit fours, tea biscuit, fruit, salad, and a crumpet?? You will absolutely walk away feeling stuffed and satisfied!

They have plenty of tea services aside from the Queen's service, so if you're looking for a more inexpensive tea service, Lovejoy's has a myriad of options. And if none of those options catch your eye, you can customize your own service or even order from their a la carte menu. 

Their tea menu is expansive as well and ranges across black teas, herbal teas, decaffeinated, fruit teas, etc, so again, you're bound to find something you'll love.

What impresses me the most about Lovejoy's tea service is how much choice you have in deciding your food items. High tea is one of my favorite indulgences, but it can be very restrictive in that the menu of what is served is pre-fixe unless you let the restaurant know ahead of time about your food allergies/restrictions. With Lovejoy's you can choose which tea sandwiches you want with your tea service, and they have plenty of meat, seafood, and vegetarian options. You can also choose which petit fours you want from a tray that they bring around to you that includes mini cakes, marzipans, chocolates, etc. I like that as a person with allergies and a food restriction (I am a pescatarian), I don't have to inform Lovejoy's ahead of time of these restrictions because their tea menu caters to everyone and all potential restrictions. 

I also love the decor of this tea room. Lovejoy's Tea Room is decorated just like a cute quintessential English tea room, with lovely pastel colors throughout, fine teapots and cups, floral wallpaper, lace curtains and tablecloths, and embroidered pillows and couches where there weren't chairs. 

Lovejoy's is truly a special tea room in Noe Valley, and it's a tea room I will definitely be coming back to again and again!
author: Pooja M.

description:
The one place where EVERYONE is wearing floral. They have a great selection of Teas, ranging from black, green, and non-caffeine. The white peach was my favorite and the apricot was also a great choice.

The menu is a bit confusing in comparison to other high tea I've attended. You have to pick what service you would like and the sandwiches. The service allows you to choose up to 2 sandwiches, which doesn't offer much variety. I recommend coming with a group of 4, so that you can share and get a little bit of everything. If you don't want to do a "set service" you can order items a la carte. The food wasn't standout amazing, but a nice experience. I was never asked if I wanted to try another tea, but just had it refilled. It would have been nice to be able to change it up, since it unlimited pots of tea

Made reservations! It tends to get busy and there is a 2 hours max seating.
author: Lisa L.

description:
My friend and I love checking out all the high tea places San Francisco offers.  This one has been on my list for quite some time, especially because I've seen it in several magazines and travel shows.

I, too, recommend going to Lovejoy's Tea Room for high tea.  They definitely have their aesthetic down.  The atmosphere is very English grandma.  There's cute knick knacks everywhere, and they even have hats available for you to wear while you dine!

What I like about their menu is that you can choose your sandwiches.  I don't eat beef, and there have been some times where I can't substitute items without changing my entire order.  I got the turkey with dijon mustard and artichoke hummus for my Queen's tea.  They were both very good.  The Queen's tea also came with a salad and coleslaw.  I wasn't a fan of the salad because it has arugula.  I'm not an fan of it, but it did go well with the coleslaw, which had the right amount of dressing.  I'm glad there was salad, though, because I needed some greens with this meal.

Like most high teas, the Queen's tea came with scones, crumpets, lemon curd, fruit preserves/jam, and Devon cream.  I really liked that it also came with fresh fruit.  You also get a tea biscuit and your choice of a petit four at the end.

Some of the other places I've gone to were heavy on the desserts.  Lovejoy's isn't, which is fantastic.  I usually feel like I'm going into diabetic shock, but I felt that dining hear was well balanced.

And as for the tea, I got blood orange, and it was delicious.  I didn't need any sugar at all.  

Service was fantastic.  I felt welcomed and well taken care of.

I suggest making reservations as this place is very popular.  And give yourself at least 30 minutes to find parking if you're driving.
author: Vira P.

description:
What a fantastic experience for a mommy daughter date. The service was exceptional the food was delicious and my daughter absolutely loved every moment of it. They made her feel so special and took time to explain all the menu items and how it worked. The decor is perfect with every cup and sauce was unique. We will definitely be back! 

Make sure to reserve your table we went on a Friday morning and there was a line but everyone was seated.
author: MM P.

description:
Lovejoy gets a solid 4 stars from me! They are probably the most popular tea room in sf and I can see why. Their atmosphere is the perfect amount of gimmicky but not TOO gimmicky. Their food is pretty good albeit on the smaller portion side. Their price is ok, not the most expensive. I have been here numerous times, including with a large group, and the service has always been impeccable. I think they are a solid tea room in a not bad location. 

In terms of food and value, I would still say Dartealing Lounge and sip tea room have better food and are a better value (more food for less price.) However, the service and atmosphere here was much better than Dartealing Lounge (it feels classy here rather than childish/janky) and the location is probably more convenient for most people compare to sip tea room (my favorite of the bunch.) Really you cannot go wrong at lovejoy.
author: Jocelyn K.

description:
I loved Lovejoy's the first time I went there a few years ago, and came back recently for a friend's birthday. It wasn't quite as magical as my first time here, but this is still one of the most authentic and best tea rooms in the Bay Area. My friend made reservations for our group a couple months in advance, and reservations are highly recommended! Make sure your group is on time, since they only give you 2-2.5 hours for your seating. It was completely packed at 11am on a Sunday. 

We all ordered the Queen's Tea (Choice of Two Sandwiches, Served w/Cabbage Salad, Caraway Cream Dressing, Organic Spring Greens, Scone w/Preserves & Devon Cream, Crumpet w/Meyer Lemon Curd, Fresh Fruit, Petit Four, Tea Biscuit, $29.95, https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=wzNGMt87QuKAu7vzCjTXQw&userid=76vIFZcC7owykCBjMfGVXg). We tried the following sandwiches and teas:

-Roast Beef & Horseradish: There wasn't much roast beef in this, and the horseradish wasn't very strong.
-Egg & Onion: Yum- great version of egg salad, but very onion-y.
-Chicken-Apple-Walnut Salad: Just ok for me, but I don't like nuts in chicken salad.
-Smoked Salmon & Cream Cheese: Solid smoked salmon & cream cheese:

-Tea Room Blend: Solid black tea, and easy to drink.
-Chestnut Tea: I loved the chestnut aroma, but this tea was STRONG. You definitely needed to add a good amount of milk to dilute it.

You can order unlimited teas, but the tables are small, and we didn't have room for a lot of teas. I wish I had tried: Apricot, Pomegranate Green, Genmai Cha, Jasmine, and White Peach.

The scone was my favorite part of the tea- it was buttery and flaky, and super delicious smothered in Devonshire double cream and lemon curd. The crumpet was just ok for me since it's meant to be more dry/chewy. I chose the peanut butter petit four, and that was really good. Although the tea service isn't cheap at $29.99, we actually had a ton of leftovers, and you're also paying for the experience. This is a great place to go with a group of girlfriends and have a British high tea experience! I heard that their Redwood City location is actually more spacious than SF, so will definitely have to check that out next time since that's closer to home. Parking actually wasn't difficult to find on a Sunday, since there were a good amount of street parking spots available.
author: Amy D.

description:
This tea room is absolutely adorable. I took my mom here to celebrate her birthday and she loved it.

It's a very eclectic and charming place, various old timey photos adorn the walls. I didn't get any pictures of it, but there's also a chandelier made out of tea cups and a welcome mat made from broken tea cup pieces. 

I like that they have various levels/price points for the tea service. You can also order things a la carte, or a plate. So even if you are on a budget, you can enjoy yourself provided you spend the minimum 11.95 per person. 

There's no shortage of options and the people working there understand - they give you ample time to decide on what you want.

My mom ordered the Queen's Tea Service and I ordered the Cream Tea. We chose the White Peach and Forest Berry tea. Both were really good, though I preferred the sweeter Forest Berry tea.

We came on a Wednesday at 11 am and there was already a large crowd. Luckily we made reservations in advance. I highly recommend making reservations.

The staff was very nice. They even brought out a mini dessert and candle for my mom, which was appreciated. 

This is a great spot for a birthday celebration or brunch, or even a date. When you're done, you can go to Lovejoy's attic across the street and visit their tea cellar.
author: Merisenda A.

description:
Lovejoy's is the first tea room establishment I've been to in San Francisco and i had a good time overall. My friends and I (a party of 8) reserved a table for Sunday @1pm. Table could probably seat 9-10 people.  The room itself has cute decor all around and multiple other tables for customers. The teacups, plates, and teapots are super cute as well and they made me feel so fancy. They have a good selection of teas, sandwiches, desserts, and other food you can order. The food that was part of the Queens Tea set may have looked small but it was surprisingly filling. Even the restroom was cute too!

The scone was the first item to eat. That was the best scone I've had in my life. I thought it was absolutely delicious. Of the sandwiches we got, I recommend the egg and onion one if you don't know what to pick. That was the tastiest one and was the favorite one by far between the 8 of us. We also had the salmon, bay shrimp, apple, and chicken apple walnut sandwiches but they weren't that extraordinary; just all tasted like cream cheese/mayo/creamy dairy product. Salmon would be number 2 pick. If you're wondering what the chocolate truffle tea tastes like, save yourself the hassle and don't even get it. It was definitely our least favorite tea out of the ones we got. I liked the vanilla tea more than i expected so that was a lovely surprise.

Lastly, a few more things: It was very loud in there so it was hard to hear each other in the room. Try to go on a less busy day if you can for a more relaxing atmosphere. We also has a 2 hour time limit so we couldn't just sit there and chat too long. That's unfortunate as we would have loved to stay longer.

If you love places like this and want to go to an even nicer one, there's one in Pasadena that's lovely. It's like Lovejoy but taken to another level. Can't remember the name but a quick search should do.
author: Lily F.

description:
Love Lovejoy's !
I did not realize it changed ownership.
Been coming here for years .
Everything Seems like before, the only slight change , I think they may be putting too little tea in the pot , as both of our teas never got strong enough .
Service still efficient, they have always had warm and attentive service.
I wish they would feature watercress sandwiches , for at least the special , it's really a quintessential tea sandwich .
Most teas service does not include salad and slaw , they do, and I must say , salad dressing is so good & the slaw w the caraway seeds , is perfect .
Special occasions or just to slip away , this tea house gets it right .
It's a treat , worth indulging!!
Check it out!!!
author: Ellie O.

description: Went here for tea, when we got our bill we were charged double for one crumpet.  Charged $5.95 for what was stated as $2.95 on the menu. They charged us nearly $6 for one crumpet since we were sharing it. Dissatisfied with the tricky sales tactics we did not leave a tip. We left to go look at their store across the street when someone from the tea room followed us and interrogated us why we didn't leave a tip. Very unprofessional and hostile environment.
author: Allison C.

description:
5 stars for the ambiance and food, but subtracting a star for service

I adore afternoon tea, so I got a group of girls together to try out the Lovejoy's in Noe Valley. I made reservations two weeks or so in advance for afternoon tea for 6 people on Saturday at 1:30 pm. There was still quite a bit of availability.

I'm glad that they have a much easier to use reservation system in place now through Resy; I had looked into coming here before but was always put off by having to fill out a form on their website.

We were quickly seated at a large table that could have accommodated up to 8 easily. Good to know for the future that they can accept larger groups.

First thing I noticed was the decor - everything was absolutely adorable! There were so many small thoughtful touches we loved. For example, on a shelf next to our table, we saw a Mrs. Potts and Chip tea pot and cup. I can tell there was a lot of thought that went into the decorations to create a quaint look for afternoon tea.

Our server told us it was easier for them if we all ordered the same set, so we all opted for the High Tea set ($22.95), which comes with your choice of two sandwiches, salad, a scone, a tea biscuit, and your choice of tea. For my two sandwiches, I went with the smoked salmon and chicken salad with pesto, which was one of their daily specials.

Instead of us each getting our food individually on a small tower, they actually placed all of our sandwiches together in one tower, which I was little disappointed about initially as I had wanted a picture with just my food. But the tower was really cute so it was hard to stay upset :) The smoked salmon sandwich was good, but I was really blown away by the chicken salad sandwich...it tasted super fresh and I could not get enough.

For my tea, I went with the mango, which both smelled and tasted delicious! I kind of wish I had gotten the decaf version afterwards though, as I was jittery for the rest of the day as my body tried to process all the caffeine.

The scone was also delicious. It came with a spread of cream and jam, and even though I knew the scone was already very rich (I've seen how much butter goes into scone recipes before...), the cream and especially the jam were totally worth the extra calories! 

I was worried that the high tea set wouldn't be enough food, as I was pretty hungry after skipping breakfast, but I was stuffed by the end and even had trouble finishing the last couple bites of the scone. 

So why the -1 star for service? Our server (forgot her name) just didn't seem to be in a good mood or something, as her attitude towards us was curt and almost mean at times. I didn't realize there was a 2 hour limit, so by the time 3:30 rolled around, she told us we needed to leave in a not-so-polite way. My friends and I were all kind of put off by her attitude, but luckily we didn't need deal with her too much so it didn't detract too much from what was otherwise a great experience.

Random note: one of my friends was vegetarian and I was pleasantly surprised by how many vegetarian sandwich options were on the menu. Definitely a vegetarian friendly spot :)
author: Dianna H.

description:
My friend had her baby shower here a few years ago and it was such a charming place for a shower. The hosts/servers made us feel at home and kept the tea and finger sandwiches flowing. The whole event was so organized and even though the whole place was crowded and busy, it seemed like we had the place to ourselves and everything went smoothly. We were there a couple hours and it was just the right amount of time to conduct our shower activities as well as enjoy each others' company while sipping tea and eating cute little sandwiches.

Although I'm not British, I grew up with teatime and I miss the tradition. I would definitely bring my mom, mother-in-law or a grandparent here to enjoy a lovely afternoon of tea and good conversation. I also think it would appeal to little girls and boys who love tea parties.
author: L. L.

description: We had a lovely tea here today, ordered the cream tea and the scones were AMAZING! A relaxed spot, whether you're famished or just want some scones and a bottomless pot of your favorite tea! We will definitely be back for more!
author: Val S.

description:
If you have never been to afternoon tea before, like I had not before coming here, I think you'll really enjoy it. This place is very quaint and cute. It's ambience is like quirky british grandparents. This place is great for a group of gal pals wanting to gossip and catch up. You feel kind of fancy, but also just whimsical. They also have a store next door where you can buy paraphernalia and teas. 

The teas were quite tasty and flavorful. The teapots were decently sized and the food is decent. At a tea place, I wouldn't expect the most delicious food but it's bite-sized and lets you have fun with it. The scones were quite delicious and matches well with the teas. There is also a good variety of food items and tea to choose from.

The Chicken-Apple-Walnut Salad and Smoked Salmon & Cream Cheese sandwiches were my favorite. The tea service options can get a bit pricey, but you are paying for the uniqueness of the experience here. Definitely need a reservation if you're trying to go at all over the weekend. 

Positives:
+ Unique experience
+ Variety of food and teas

Negatives:
- Can get pricy

Recommend:
+ Scone with Preserves and Devon Cream
+ Chestnut tea & Earl grey tea
+ Chicken-Apple-Walnut Salad sandwich
+ Smoked Salmon & Cream Cheese sandwich
author: Angie N.

description: Very cute and fun environment. Love the finger foods and vibe. My friends and I enjoyed our time there. The service was wonderful.
author: Stephanie G.

description:
This place is cute. After having my first official afternoon tea in London during our honeymoon, I was dying for another opportunity to enjoy such an experience. My husband is the greatest and made reservations at this spot. What a sport - he was the only guy in the joint and didn't complain, just let me enjoy my tea. 

I had the Me Tea - a bottomless pot (although I could only handle one pot) of brown rice and popcorn green tea, a scone with butter and jam, and a tomato and cheddar sandwich. The presentation was adorable although a bit more rustic than our fancy London experience. I love the character of all mismatched serve ware but was a little bummed about the cleanliness (a stained ring around the rim of my husband's tea cup prior to pouring tea, sediment buildup at the bottom of my tea pot) but it is fine. We are talking about tea in San Francisco, not a high end spot in London. My tea was delicious and the scone was probably one of the best I've had. 

Midway through, I started to get a mild allergic reaction (light swelling of my lips but nothing crazy). I have a nut allergy and didn't think to mention it before ordering since what I ordered should have been nut free - totally my fault and not at all theirs - but when I asked if anything had nuts, the server quickly responded "no" and carried on. I popped a benedryl and continued on enjoying my tea. It would have been nice to know so that I can let you guys know and be aware for myself next time that maybe the butter had ground walnuts (sounds crazy but I've experienced this elsewhere before), or the scones were made with almond flour, but got no such explanation. If you have an allergy, I would be sure to ask first and clearly state so if you have a severe allergy but also be prepared just in case. 

The worst part, the thing that warrants a 3-star review, was the service in my opinion. It felt VERY rushed even though they weren't busy. We had reservations and were immediately seated - awesome. We ordered shortly thereafter and our food arrived within a few minutes - okay great. But then, as I was finishing my food and sipping my tea, the check arrived. I didn't even have time to order another pot if I wanted to, it just felt so rushed. We still sat there for another 10 minutes after paying because I wanted to finish the pot I was currently on (afterall, at $10 a pot, you should be able to enjoy more than a cup or two). I think we were there for a total of 40 minutes. That combined with the nonchalance of the allergy mention above made me a little bummed about the customer service.

Nonetheless it is a cute place and I'd hope you'd have a better experience than we did. I'd say we'd give it another shot, but there are other tea places that I will likely want to try instead to get an experience worthy of the price tag that comes with an afternoon tea.
author: Ashley F.

description:
My friend and I love trying new places for tea. This had been on our list for awhile and we decided to try it one Saturday. 
We came for afternoon tea, I absolutely loved the big selection on teas as well as being able to choose your sandwiches. Some tea places give you so many sweets which is another thing I did like about this tea time, they give you a sweet at the end and it's a good selection. 
The only thing I didn't like and it's my personal preference, it felt a little overwhelming. It does give off a cluttered vibe. I just felt cramped, it also can be very loud and i had trouble hearing my friend when we were talking. Not sure if I would return, maybe...
author: Veronica V.

description:
Sub-par cream tea, I'm afraid. 

Considering how cute the place looks, and how busy, and how good the reviews are, I was expecting something wonderful and invited an out-of-town guest for an afternoon tea. We walked in on a weekday afternoon and were immediately seated. It wasn't busy at all. As everyone says it's quite another matter on weekends. The service was perfectly fine. The food and the tea were sub-par.

I feel I must explain what Cream Tea is before I review what I was served.  A cream tea doesn't mean tea which is creamy. A cream tea is a scone served with clotted cream, optionally (though usually) also jam, and a pot of tea. It is a kind of set piece. Clotted cream is a kind of delicious creamy thing about halfway between the most delicate butter you've ever had and whipped cream. It is, not too put too fine a point on it, the very heart of cream tea. You want a generous amount of it. I know all this from having had a great deal of cream tea in England in a variety of tea places. 

I ordered cream tea, which came with two scones, about a scant tablespoon of clotted cream, a little bit of jam, and some fresh fruit. A tablespoon of clotted cream is not enough for one scone, never mind for two. There should have been at least three times that much clotted cream. I am not exaggerating or being facetious. You want to be able to spread a thick amount of clotted cream and then have enough left to lick out of the container like a barbarian, if you can get away with it. I understand that they are importing clotted cream in tiny jars from the UK at great expense, but considering how much the whole cream tea costs, I think they could afford to be more generous with the stuff. It's also possible to make your own clotted cream from scratch, and the only problem is you have to make rather a lot of it at once which shouldn't be such an issue for a shop that specializes in tea. 

Inexplicably, the scones were heated up. I realize it says that on the menu and perhaps I ought not to have been surprised. But I was surprised because scones should not be warmed up. They should be fresh, but not warm and certainly not re-warmed. Rewarming scones is just not done. I don't know how else to put that. It's incorrect. Aside from it being not done, it's also a bad idea because it will melt your delicious clotted cream and ruin its texture and coolness. It also can't be good for the texture of the scones. 

These were raisin scones, which in my experience are sometimes a bit more solid rather than crumbly, and maybe if they had not been re-heated they would have been on the far end of the acceptable range of scone textures. They were not the right texture. They utterly lacked any crumbliness. Sure, if you're used to Starbucks scones, you might be impressed. But if you are expecting an English style scone, these are not that. They are incorrect.

The jam was fine, though still a little bit less than I would really expect.

To summarize, there was not enough clotted cream and the scones were wrong.

Now let us move on to the tea. I ordered the house blend black tea, and it was a very good full-bodied tea. Milk was provided, as it should be. It was loose-leaf and came in a teapot. You had to strain it with a little strainer when pouring because the leaves are put directly in the teapot. Which is OK and I can't say it's not correct, lots of English people do it that way.

The tea was good for the first cup. Because there was no way to take out the tea leaves, it inevitably became over-brewed for subsequent cups. When I got very close to the bottom of the teapot, the waitress came by to "warm up" the pot to make good on the promise of bottomless tea. I can't be 100% sure about what happened next. Based on the flavor of the tea it seems like the old tea leaves were not replaced and either more hot water was added or more hot water with some more leaves. Anyway it was bitter and not very good a that point. The whole tea part of the experience could be improved by putting the looseleaf tea in a brewing basket (which is not heretical in any way and lots of English tea houses do it, and it's not like authenticity appears to be a concern at this teahouse). 

Everything that went wrong could be fixed with a little bit of effort and care. That's part of why I'm writing this review. I'd love for nothing more than to be able to pay slightly too much money for a very good cream tea without flying all the way to England.

Anyway, I'm sure lots of people will continue to have a nice time playing dress-up and doing England cosplay at this highly atmospheric cute little joint. Heck, maybe the sandwiches are good.
author: AK K.

description:
This was a lovely way to spend a Sunday afternoon.
I made it in just before the kitchen closed for the day.

I had finished up at Dolores park and wanted to check out something I had bookmarked that was near. 

I am so happy it was here.

I ordered a Cream Tea, a Tea pot and scones, to my delight I also got some fresh fruit with that.

The pot itself was much larger then i am used to receiving at these types of establishments. 
The decorations are adorable and the staff was attentive.
The scone was delicious, my only down side was the scone comes with devon cream and jam, which is good and all but my preferred is lemon curd with.

Lighting is good, not to cramped.
If i come again by myself I will for sure be bringing a good book. It is a great place to sit and read and enjoy your pot of tea. 

Price isn't awful either :D
author: Tabitha D.

description:
Love this tea room! It's everything a tea room should be, save not in England. But it has all the other elements to make sure you truly enjoy your experience.

This place books up early and FAST, so we made sure to make reservations. I was seated promptly and waited for my party to arrive. I love all there were several other parties nearby, yet we couldn't really hear anyone's conversation. When my party arrived, we decided to order the Queens tea, because, well why not? 

There was a great selection of teams ranging from greens to blacks to whites and herbals. It was hard to actually make a decision (which is always the probltem I like to have). I ended up with the chamomile and my friend got the white strawberry.  Both teas were delicious, and now I can't wait to go back and try others with the different food options.

Speaking of, this place has a wide selection of everything and caters to various health restrictions. For instance, pay a little more and you've got yourself some gluten-free options. 

All in all, this is a great place for relaxation and to unwind. It's also easy to find  parking as well, which is always a plus in my book
author: Tracy T.

description:
Came here thru recommendations from AirBnB, and I am glad I came. The food here is wonderful, the servers here were sweet. The server would constantly come by to check on our teas on whether we need more hot water.

It's good for anyone who likes good foods and great customer services.
author: Jane C.

description:
Solid afternoon tea. Nothing particularly special about the food or even the tea, but Lovejoy's has that cozy afternoon tea vibe and is a good spot for catching up with a friend or gathering for a birthday. It's definitely more about the company and experience than the actual food or tea.

That being said, it's kind of an expensive experience, with the cheapest tea services being about $20 and the full tea service (Queen's Tea) being $30. It's easy to make a similar experience at home for much less, but obviously without the quirky decorations around.

I ordered the HEALTHY TEA ($20), which was a large platter consisting of salad, carrots and cucumber, fruit, walnuts, crackers, cream cheese and an option of smoked salmon or artichoke hummus. Perfect if you want something lighter or if you're not into the usual scones, crumpets and sandwiches.

For my tea, I got the Black Vanilla with Lavender, which was recommended by our waitress. Couldn't really taste the lavender but it had a subtle sweetness reminiscent of vanilla. They're very good about refilling your tea pot so it's really bottomless.

Note that they do have a 2 hour limit on the tables! There's also only 1 bathroom and a consistently long line so don't wait until the last moment to get in line.
author: Jessie L.

description:
Took my mom to her first English afternoon tea, and I'm sorry to say I was disappointed. We booked this because of both friends recommendations and the high Yelp reviews.

I give one star for presentation, one star for decor, and one star goes to the scone for being on point.

Less one star for the food - sandwiches and quiche were bland. This is the first time I ever packed food to take home from an afternoon tea.

Less another star for service. When you drop $200 taking all your sisters and mom out for a child-free afternoon, I expect friendly, bubbly wait staff. They weren't exactly rude, but at one point the waitress snapped at my mom for asking her to repeat the petit four flavors. Really? 

Unfortunately, I likely won't return.
author: M J.

description:
I brought my mom here for an early mother's day meal & we had the best time! The decor is super whimsical- mismatched teacups, christmas lights, and british memorabilia. 
I made reservations for 3PM on a Thursday, and when we arrived the restaurant was about 1/3-1/2 full. The restaurant itself is pretty tiny, so I would make reservations just in case. 
We both ordered the queen's tea (2 sandwiches, cabbage salad, fruit, scone, crumpet, petit four & biscuit, and of course a bottomless pot of tea). This was a TON of food! I didn't love the sandwiches I chose, but there are a ton to pick from so I'd love to come back and try some of the others. The rest of the meal was delicious (mmm those scones though), and my mom loved the whole experience. Such a cute/fun afternoon!
author: Catherine S.

description:
If you like to indulge in afternoon high tea, this is the place for you. Invite your best girlfriends for a real treat. There are several different items you can try. I recommend the high tea which comes with two sandwiches, salad, cole slaw, and crumpets. My friend and I each ordered the high tea which also includes tea of course. The staff are lovely to boot. 

Even though the items aren't really that big, I found myself getting full after eating. It's not super noisy here so it's a good place to catch up. They also have fun hats you can wear while indulging or just take some pictures with them. It's not too far away from the 24th St Mission BART stop but there was plenty of parking in the middle of the day. It's worth checking out at least once.
author: Amy J.

description:
So cute. So quaint. My favorite place for high tea. 

We ordered the Queen's tea because we get a little bit of everything. Highlight: scones, Devon cream, lemon curd, crumpet and petite four. Ordered the following sandwiches: cucumber cream cheese, mandarin cream cheese, ham and mustard, turkey and mustard. I personally like the cucumber and mandarin sandwiches because they are light and refreshing. We ordered the savory sandwiches with a little punch of flavor to complement the lighter fare. 

The staff are so nice and accommodating. As it is high tea, we sat for about 2 hours. Staff checked on us regularly enough. We refilled our tea twice (we drink A LOT of tea). 

You get a little coupon to their retail storefront across the street Lovejoy's Attic when you dine.
author: Stephanie L.

description:
We had a large reservation for two birthdays here, but they were really good with helping me over the phone while making the reservation and with service while we were here. We had 12 adults plus a baby, so we were posted up in their largest table. It's a little bit cramped inside because it is chock full of decor, hats, and additional tables, but it wasn't much of a hassle.

For high tea for 12 (13), we were able to pick any teas off of the menu, and due to our large party we had a preorder selection of six kinds of sandwiches, along with salad, scones and cream, and tea biscuits. The salad was just some greens, nothing too special, but the scones were solid and the sandwiches as well.

We got the following sandwiches: Chicken-Apple-Walnut Salad, Roast Beef & Horseradish, Smoked Salmon & Cream Cheese, Lovejoy's Daily Special, Bay Shrimp & Mayonnaise, Pear & Stilton. They were all pretty solid, but the smoked salmon & cream cheese and the daily special were definitely the favorites.

The tea selection were all pretty solid as well, and they were pretty good with getting us more hot water or more teapots as we asked for different flavors of teas.

Many thanks for the flexibility in accommodating our large party, especially when we weren't sure how large the party was going to be during the reservation process.
author: Wayne H.

description:
I adore anything cute so naturally I was drawn to Lovejoy. I went here twice, once with my boyfriend and once for my sister's bridal shower. Both time I really enjoyed myself and left with great pictures for the IG. 

Logistics:
Making a reservation is a must! This place is crazy popular that a walk in will be difficult. I would recommend calling instead of using the reservation system they have on their site. I was able to book a reservation through the phone when the site showed no open table for the time and date I wanted. Granted they will never pick up so leaving a voicemail is the way to go as they always call you back to confirm. 

Service:
The service here treats you like a queen (or king)! They are so nice and accommodating with last minute changes and even seat you even if everyone from your party have not arrived. I know some busy places don't allow seating until everyone has arrived which may lead to some resentment towards your chronically tardy friends lol. 

Food:
High Tea - I always opt for this one since it's more than enough to fill me up. You get a choice of two sandwiches and bottomless tea. 

Tea - I recommend the white peach tea as the teapot comes with its own strainer. Also it taste great! 

Sandwich - It is roast beef/horseradish + turkey/mustard all the way for me. I just like the combo of those two. I will ventured with the daily special as well since they have sandwiches not listed on the menu. 

Queen's Tea - This one is definitely a 2 person option. It's like the high tea except you get fruits and a dainty dessert at the end.  

Blueberry scone - Everyone raves about this scone and it's definitely the highlight! Definitely try it with the jam (but it's already really good by itself). 

Overall: 
I would definitely come back if I want to feel a little classy and drink tea with my pinky up. The price is also very decent for the service, atmosphere, and food you get. In my opinion, it's the best high tea in the city.
author: Annie V.

description:
Dec 2017:
No apologies on the horrible service. Server only topped off our tea hot water one time during 1 hr 45 mins. Server did not check in with us after initial serving. 

Rushed: Then, we are not done eating at 1 hr in, and the server comes by with desert tray. I wanted to say that we weren't quite ready for it, that we felt rushed, but instead we said no thank you. Shortly after that the check appeared on our table.

One of the two new owners stopped by, saying "I hear there's been a problem." I explain the situation to her. No recognition at all that something has changed in their service or that there's something amiss. 

She then tells me that we are supposed to flag down the server if we want more hot water for our tea. Since when? Like many of you I have been to tea rooms in many places, in many places, including England. And nowhere does the customer have to flag the server down for hot water. It is their job to come by and do a refill.

The Correct attitude of the new owner would be to say, yes I understand that we haven't done enough, our service has not been up to standards. The fact is, since the new ownership, the service has actually been fine. Why it was different this time I don't know. I have been here before Christmas with the new owners, so it can't be that. It's the attitude that I don't appreciate. After years of enjoying this place under the former owners tutelage, this new situation is sad.

Food: They seem to have gotten the food right now with Sandwiches, scones, and salads. They seem to have ironed out the kinks in the food since they took over from the original owner. I'm sad to say that the service is driving me and others away from this business.

Earlier--
September 2016: 
Scones much improved. Perhaps it's an entirely different purveyor that they are acquiring them from? Service good as always. 
The main problem: the scented products in the bathroom. The first of our party to go in there came back and warned us. I went and asked someone about it for going in. Finally I had to talk to the owner and she removed the products. Honestly, it's a tiny space and I have a medical issue. But even my friend-- she couldn't breathe, her head aching afterwards. I could see having the usual scented soap in there has a lingering effect, but please consider people who can't abide by scented products let alone blasting it in a small space. 

August 2016:
New owners have taken charge. No more Muna! Please give them feedback so that they can maintain this wonderful business. 
Along with the two scones which were undercooked, we received the usual raspberry jam, watery whipping cream which did not barely fill the thimble size container, and no lemon curd. They have added a few sandwiches to the menu, which is fine. I would not make any more changes at the moment, and instead concentrate on maintaining quality. Service was good as usual, attentive, lovely, personable. Sandwiches were good. Tea good.
author: Cleo B.

description:
Made reservations for Lovejoy's on their website for 11 AM. Be sure to do the same. When we arrived the tables were all reserved. 

The restaurant is outfitted with English decor. There is a hat rack with hats that you might be able to wear. 

We opted for the High tea. There is another higher level set with more food. But, we ended up really being stuffed, so I'd recommend the High tea unless you are absolutely starving. It's much cheaper too. 

Our server was nice and friendly and suggested teas and sandwiches that we might like. There was another server that did, however, give a far more detailed explanation of the menu to another party. 

For tea, I chose Chestnut. My girlfriend chose Apricot. Mine wasn't suited to me. My girlfriend, being awesome as she is, tried mine and liked it, so we switched. I really liked the Apricot. They freshen up the tea for you after a bit and give you huge potfuls. 

I was able to choose two sandwiches for my set. The two that I chose were salmon and chicken salad with walnuts. The sandwiches were good not great. 

Also included was a wonderful cabbage salad with Carraway cream dressing. I scarfed that one down. 

The organic spring greens were a little wilted. 

The highlight of the set had to be the scone! Nice and warm with currants. I recommend spooning some Devon cream and preserves on each bite. Super yummy!

I think the next time that I come here I will go straight for the tea and scones. I'd like to try a crumpet as well!
author: Sean A.

description:
Super cute place to have afternoon tea! I had the Queen's Tea, which was a substantial amount of food for one person (but don't worry, I finished it). I got the cucumber and cream cheese sandwich as well as the artichoke hummus and they were both divine.

For tea I got the chestnut black tea and it was INCREDIBLE. It was highly recommended by several members of the staff and I'm SO glad I went with their suggestion. I even ended up buying some from their (also adorable) "attic" store across the street!
author: Angela M.

description: Just like everything else that was good in the city, lovejoys apparently has become the latest sellout. The last couple of times i've come here i noticed that the new owners lack the British charm, the hospitality and most of all the portions that Lovejoys was so well known for under previous ownership. Portions have become incredibly stingy and trust me as i have been going here for nearly a decade. I always get the same thing, the egg and onion salad and smoked salmon and cream cheese sandwiches. There is barely any smoked salmon in there and the tiny layer that is there covers about half. The same with the egg salad being a very thinly spread layer and it was extremely over salt especially today. The crumpets have gone up for two pieces ($4 for one crumpet, seriously?!) the teas don't taste as strong (i always get the tea room blend) prices have gone up and service is not very warm or friendly, except for when you're asking for the check. Saying that i'm very disappointed is an understatement!
author: Petra S.

description:
Simply put, I love Lovejoy's Tea Room.

Just entering the tea room, I felt incredibly happy and giddy. Although the decor consisted of beautiful mismatched items, it was still in good taste. There are hats available for you to wear during your tea time. 

I ordered the Light Tea set ($19.95) with Chinese Rose Petal black tea while my boyfriend ordered the High Tea set ($21.95) with English Breakfast black tea. The portioning of the Light Tea set was perfect for me. I highly enjoyed the rose petal tea. Both of our tea pots were constantly being refilled without us having to call a waitress over. We were well taken care of by the staff. 

I made a reservation for two about a month in advance. I highly recommend you make a reservation, especially if you are planning on coming on a weekend. 

The tea room is perfect for all types of parties: couples, parents with their young children, and friends catching up.
author: Katie C.

description: We got a Queens Tea and a High Tea set. The food was decent but nothing special. The scones were pretty good - which is what I came for. I think it was overpriced for the amount of food and quality. The decor was very cute but kind of old (frays and stains). Maybe I was expecting too much, but it definitely doesn't compare to tea service in the UK.
author: Tina G.

description: My afternoon tea sweetie and I both love this place! Cute decorations and good food. We both had the Queen's tea that comes with a variety of goodies. Highlight is the house blend black tea, strong and flavorful.
author: Sandy T.

description:
What a lovely place is Lovejoy's for an English tea service! The most memorable parts of this restaurant are definitely the flamboyant decorations and the beautiful mismatched china and flatware. I came (with a reservation) right when they opened on a Saturday with a group of four, and it was a great place to sit back, relax, and chat. Unlike some other tea rooms, there's nothing stuck-up or overly formal about this place; it's a rather casual spot to get tea--there are kids all around and no need to dress up as for a formal occasion.

Each one of us decided to order the High Tea set, which came with a selection of two tea sandwiches, cole slaw, salad, a scone, and a tea biscuit, along with a bottomless pot of tea. I went with the decaf chocolate truffle tea, which had a deep chocolatey aroma, but not a lot of chocolate flavor. I got to try the artichoke hummus, bay shrimp, chicken/asparagus, and pear/stilton sandwiches, and while all of them were good, they were definitely on the small side and didn't have much filling. The cole slaw salad was refreshing, but completely overpowered by the caraway seeds. The highlight of the food was the currant scone. The scone was soft, fluffy, warm, and tender, pairing perfectly with the clotted cream and raspberry preserves!

Overall, a great neighborhood place to get tea. Though the food portions were not huge, this was a decent price for what we got, and I'd definitely recommend Lovejoy's for a laid back yet elegant tea service experience!
author: David K.

description:
I love high tea.. So I was dying to try this spot! I happened to be in the neighborhood with my husband so he decided to treat me. As I walked in to inquire for a table, I was greeted with a terrible look from the hostess. I asked if I can get a table for two. The spot was NOT full whatsoever and there was even outdoor seating free.. before I could speak, the hostess said: sorry, were full. 
I mentioned I didn't mind waiting and coming back at a later time, I was really excited to eat here! She then proceeded to tell me it was an hour to two hour wait. I told her I didn't mind but she was VERY hesitant about putting my name down for a table. Don't think she liked the idea of two gay men enjoying high tea at her business..

I waited and waited for my call but never heard from them. I walked past later just to see if the place was full and there was literally more free tables an hour before closing. I was too hurt to even ask again. What crazy times we live in..

HOW CAN A PLACE CALLED LOVEJOY BE SO HATEFUL?
author: Victor-Hugo W.

description:
There are so many wrong things about this place that I don't know where to begin. 

From the passive aggressive, anxious staff, to the barely edible food, all the way to the outrageously overpriced menu which lacks value. The tea selection is basic, they skimp on the sandwiches content so much, that honestly, it doesn't matter what you're going to pick, they all taste like boring white bread. Oh, and it's $2 for a little jam and $2 for a little butter to go with your very dry  4$ scone.

Unfortunately, this place is a gimmick, living on its faded glory.

This city has so many remarkable places, that my only advice is to STAY AWAY.
author: Beckett C.

description:
First and last time at Lovejoy's Tea Room. 
I went there with my wife and daughter hoping to have an enjoyable experience, and fair enough the tea and food were good, but the service ended up being terrible.  It ruined the experience. 
The place is charming enough although very cramped, and as I mentioned the food was good but nothing out of the ordinary. The staff was mostly unavailable/inattentive, and condescending about tea.
author: Philip W.

description:
I'm a huge fan of English-style afternoon tea, so when some friends and I decided to try this place I was super excited. We had to make a reservation, and I highly recommend that you do too. We went in the middle of the day on a Friday and the place was filled to the brim of people. There is no waiting area inside, and only a couple of small benches outside. They would not let us in properly until our actual reservation time, even though the table we ended up at was empty when we arrived a couple minutes early.

It's a small tea shop, and the tables are tiny. I felt a bit squished, and had to hold myself rather awkwardly still so as to try not to break anything, or trip over the servers. The slightly uncomfortable seat didn't help with this.

$26 for a tower of 4 triangle sandwiches, 1 scone, a protein-less salad, and a couple of sweets seem rather steep to me. Flavor was bland on all items. The only thing I really liked was the texture of the scone.

Pros: Bottom-less teapot, and they do have other items on the menu like sheperd's pie. I kinda wish I had gotten that, with a scone on the side, instead of the tea set. There's also an awesome smelling room of loose tea for sale in the affiliated shop directly across from the street.

In the end? I would only come here if it was a social thing. Otherwise, I'm going to stick to afternoon teas either a) made at home for much cheaper and more flavor, or b) at places like the Peninsula instead.
author: Bonnie N.

description: We have been trying to go here for years when we used to live in Sacramento and never had the opportunity. We were in town for a wedding and decided to stop by they were all full and we didn't have a reservation but we told them that we were really wanting to go here for years, they made an accommodation although it was small it was perfect. The teas were amazing and the food, and the scones were the best scones I have ever had in my life. Definitely coming back here when we are in SF. This is a great place for little girls they also have hats and decor to wear while you are in there.
author: Madeeha B.

description: I've never been to Lovejoy's and not loved it. It's a truly charming and sweet high tea experience. It's not super glam like the Palace Hotel's garden court, but it's way more intimate, comfortable. The food and tea is better than most high tea place I've been in the city, and priced lower than the higher end places. I especially love all the eccentric tea ware and everybody gets a different set. Bonus that even though the main clientele are ladies, every guy I've ever taken to have tea at this place loved it, so take your man there next time!
author: Yi Y.

description:
I recently went twice and got Queen's Tea one time and High Tea the other time. Both are good options but I definitely prefer High Tea and will probably get that from now on. The reason I prefer High Tea over Queen's Tea is that Queen's Tea is $7 more and only gives you a crumpet, some fruit, and a Petit Four. Personally I don't really enjoy crumpets or Petit Fours so that basically means $7 for a bit of fruit. However, if you love crumpets and Petit Fours, go for it! I can finish the whole High or Queen's Tea myself so it makes me full but doesn't keep me full for more than an hour or two. However, the experience is really fun and cute for special occasions. If you're looking for a light fruity tea, one of my personal favorites is White Peach.

The environment itself is very old fashioned and cute with pretty, mismatched dishes. Everyone is friendly there too. However, both times I came with a party of 3 and got stuck at the table with the "shared" bench, meaning you share a bench with someone from another table. The time I sat on that bench, I felt every time the girl sitting on the other side moved or rocked it (because of course it's not level). I plan to now go with either one other person or a party of 4+ now unless they replace that bench haha. Don't forget to make reservations (which you can do online)!
author: Amanda L.

description: 1 Year Wedding Anniversary: wanted to celebrate our marriage overseas with a lovely cup of tea. Arrived at 4:50PM and were denied a table (open tables everywhere). Told last seating was at 4:30PM. Just wanted a cup of tea with my wife. Drove 45 mins to this location. Very disappointed.
author: Nathan B.

description: Such an adorable place! It can get a bit loud at times but the decor is cute and classy! Staff there is super nice and accommodating, they make good recommendations too. Very dainty, love the attic store too.
author: Runa M.

description: There are a couple restaurants in the city for high tea, and I've tried just about every one of them. Lovejoy's is such a cute spot! At first it seems like there isn't a lot of treats on the table, but once you start eating you realize the food is quite filling. I love the quaint, welcoming atmosphere.
author: Ali R.

description:
It's such a cute experience! 

I think that out of all the tea rooms that I've been to, this one is the best. I came here twice in the span of two weeks because I know so many of my friends have always wanted to try this. 

Once I got the high tea and another time I got the light tea. 

When I got the high tea, you can get two sandwiches. I picked the artichoke hummus/arugula and the roast beef with horseradish. Both of these sandwiches were good and they were a good balance to each other. It came with a salad and scone. It kept me surprisingly full! 
I picked the white strawberry tea. It was so yummy and light. I didn't add any cream or sugar into it at all. I think it was too light for the cream and sugar. 

The second time I came, I ordered the light tea but added a crumpet on the side. I think that I liked this tea service a lot better. It still made me full and instead of the salad, there was fruit. I think that it was nice to have some sweet. The salad from the high tea didn't excite me in anyway. The sandwich that I got for this tea service was the chicken walnut. I think I would have went with another sandwich for next time. I got the decaf mango black tea. It got pretty strong after sitting for a while. I didn't add cream and sugar when it was lighter, but my second and third cup I put in the works. 

I would say that this is kind of pricey for what it is, but this place is really more for the experience more than anything. It's nice food to chat over.
author: Tina Y.

description:
Very cute place. Had like an Alice in Wonderland vibe for me. 

I went with my friend to have some tea time and we were both pleased with the service and food. We were greeted when we walked in and got sat down with our reservations. They told us what was the daily special that day and brought everything out in a timely manner. Food and service was great. The food didn't seem like much, but filled both me and my friend. 

Would come again.
author: Vernice T.

description: A perfect spot to enjoy afternoon tea with friends.  Our reservations was at 4pm but I came 15 minutes early.  Not an issue as they have our tables ready and promptly seated me while I wait for the rest of my party.  The decor was on point and the mismatched tea sets were adorable!  We ordered two sets Queen's tea which had fruits, salad, scones, sandwiches, and crumpets.  The scones were scrumptious (especially with lemon curd) and the tea sandwiches were divine (my fave was the egg and onions and the apple and cream cheese)!  We tried the peppermint tea, and the peach green tea- both very good and refreshing.  Definitely a good place to hang out when you are in Noe Valley.
author: Notsky P.

description: I ordered the queens tea. It comes with fresh fruit two sandwiches, salad, coleslaw, scones, crumpets tea cookies and petite fours and of course a bottomless pot of your choice of tea. The Queens tea was about ~$29 per person. You can't go wrong with the tea, and their scones are so good and buttery and are warm when you get them. We got the smoked salmon/cream cheese, chicken walnut apple and pear and Stilton sandwiches. The smoked salmon was delicious, pear was ok and I would skip the chicken walnut apple next time. Their fruit was sweet and the coleslaw lacked flavor and the salad was just the greens, mandarin oranges with balsamic vinaigrette. The crumpets come half way through and we're nice and hot. The petite fours were sweet and a nice touch to the end. Over all I would come again but maybe just get the tea, scones, a crumpet and maybe even one sandwich.
author: Michelle P.

description:
Customer service here is so bad!!  We got here 30 minutes before our reservations at 11am.  Since it was really cold outside and I had a young daughter, I asked if we could wait inside.  The person here was so reluctant and didn't want us to stay inside - she finally let us stay but had such a bad attitude.  There are no stores nearby that I could have killed time.

Will not be coming back.
author: Nicole S.

description:
Fantastic little outing, especially for moms/girls/friends looking to partake in the classic tea time experience with with the Alice in Wonderland feel.

Everything here reminds me of a distant friend's attic full of small treasures and collectibles from family moves and heirlooms.  The mismatched approach creates an even more cute and colorful palette, rustic right down to the chairs and tables.

Service her is warm and friendly so be prepared to be pampered.  Please note that this establishment gets packed quickly and if you don't have reservations, good luck trying to do a walk-in.  People make reservations here in advance.

We ordered the Queen's Tea Service, which is an assortment of both savory and sweet items.  The savory sandwiches are cut cleanly in quarters and are devoid of crust *yay* while the sweet items (scones are DIVINE) lever a balance between sips of bottomless teas.

Cute outing with the girls and definitely affordable (tea service in Paris and London were costing me a cool $100 at least) so it was nice to partake in something local that was quite affordable.
author: Miika M.

description:
What a perfect place for a tea party! I came here for a meet up, place was easy to get too (parking wasn't too hard find), the service was very attentive, and the inside decor was very quaint. Plus there was plenty of space so you didn't all feel on top of each other.

The mini sandwiches and scones provided tasted very fresh. Since we had a large group I could sample of all the black and herbal teas since the group like those the most.

Would recommend this place for anyone wanting to have a tea party, tea date, or just want tea!
author: Vanessa S.

description:
Last Wednesday afternoon was a lovely day to have a cup of tea with a splendid tea service.  I wanted to call them to make reservations.  No answer.  Just an automated voice mail.  I tried leaving a voice message, and right before I made it to Lovejoy's, no response.  As I arrived at Lovejoy's Tea Room, the sign said it's closed; however, I did see people inside enjoying their tea service.  As I opened the door, a middle aged waitress in eyeglasses asked me what I'm doing here.  I responded saying I called to make reservations.  Then she told me that I should go to Lovejoy's Attic to make reservations before heading inside the tea room.  Oh dear!  Guess I should have done that.  Maybe next time.  Anyway, she did find a table for me, which is used for any majestic couples.

While seated and be given a menu to look at, I wanted to order something many Britons enjoy for generations.  I chose the Decaf version of the Earl Grey and the "Me" Tea Service.  As I look around its atmosphere, nothing smells.  Patrons in their separate tables are enjoying themselves, talking and laughing while finishing most of their meals.  It comes to show that Lovejoy's have gotten better before I come here.  Still, something has never changed.  On my right side, some portraits in black and white seemed aged.  Feels like I'm inside the very old tea room during the Victorian era.  But the songs in the background are somewhat American oldies.  (Sigh) Guess nothing's perfect.

With the Decaf Earl Grey in the bottomless teapot and a small pitcher of milk on my table, it wouldn't take long for a "Me" Tea Service to be served as well.  A milk tea kinda guy like me never forgets to pour his tea in a teacup in a fancy way before pouring little bit of milk and two spoonfuls of sugar.  Taste evenly sweet with familiar hints of Italian Bergamot oil.  Next was my "Me" Tea.  Four right triangular tea sandwiches made with hummus spread, simply delicious.  A Devon cream with a lemon slice and a kiwi slice is super sweet.  I used it plus a whatchamacallit berry jam to smear on a scone.  Pieces of organic arugula are edible, even the Moroccan mint leaf.  My waitress was so kind to give me a refill of the Earl Grey.

In at least 45 minutes, I finished the whole tea service.  Everything is good from start to finish.  I like how the servers in Lovejoy's are doing good business, and I humbly thanked them for keeping up their good work.  Smiles!
author: Jimmy C.

description:
My sweet boyfriend took me here for my belated birthday celebration this past Sunday since I celebrated with both him & my family on my actual birthday. Originally, he made reservations at Benihana, but I prefer something that is new to us from my bookmarks therefore Lovejoy it is! 

We luckily found a good spot a few steps from Lovejoy's since it was starting to drizzle at the time. I love the heart painting on the side of the place. So cute!

We were seated at a small table next to the English red telephone booth looking cabinet. This place is very mismatch-y which really bothered my hunny cause he's like OCD. Haha.. but it's still very cozy and cute and unique little place. 

We both got the Queen's Tea for 2 while he chose the English Breakfast while I had the China Rose Petal tea. Everything was pretty delish, but the most outstanding would be the crumpets. They were warm & soft & crunchy. Yum! 

Service was friendly, sweet, and attentive. The lady which we're pretty sure is the owner is always addressing us as loveys which was very endearing. 

She brought out a candle on a present box looking petit four since he told them it was for my birthday during the reservation process. So that was nice. 

It's definitely a cute little tea place to visit if you're into high tea. :)
author: Amy C.

description: This was mine and my best friends first stop while visiting the Bay Area. Amazing service and eats! There's plenty of teas to choose from and the servers are happy to help you out when deciding between the different options they have. It is a bit cluttered, but most tea rooms I've been to have been like that.. so be aware! The interior was beautiful, there was so much to look at. We did high tea, there were a few options to choose from. Everything was delicious, they also had a variety of finger sandwiches to choose from. I would recommend making a reservation in advance because it filled up pretty fast and there's only so many tables. I can't wait to come back here when I'm visiting again!
author: Leanna U.

description:
I am so happy to finally be able to write a review for Lovejoy's Tea Room.  The first and last time I came was nearly 15 years ago for a birthday party; at the time, I was ten and loved the experience.  I kept eyeing this place for years and finally my best friend and I decided to catch up and we were able to book a table at Lovejoy's for the same week --a Wednesday at 3pm.  We went yesterday and loved every minute.  

Upon first arriving it was such a charming view to see all the tables and chairs set up with their cups, saucers, and small plates.  The mismatched china is fun to look at and compare.  The tables had a lace tablecloth and honestly, I felt like I would be joined by Jane Austen any minute.  The set up is wonderful!

The host and server was very friendly and gave us her recommendations to order our tea service.  We ordered one High Tea service to share; this included the choice of two tea sandwiches, small salad, cabbage slaw, and two scones with clotted cream and berry preserves. For the sandwiches we went for the sweet and savory: the pear and stilton & the special of the day fig tapenade with goat cheese.  Both were delicious! For our bottomless pot o' tea --the "champagne of teas" was elected: Afternoon Darjeeling.  This really was bottomless as a server would check it periodically and warm it (put more hot water in) to assure that we didn't run out in the middle of our tea service.  The presentation of the tea service was on a two-tiered stand --which gave a nice 360 view of your items to pick and choose as you ate.  
**some tables are a bit smaller and may get a bit crowded as items come  out from the kitchen, so maneuver carefully --definitely wouldn't want to break anything!** 

My friend and I enjoyed the whole experience and even looking around at the decor is fun! There is so many unique and fun items hanging around.  

Although they tea room was not very busy when we went, I'd definitely recommend making a reservation to secure a table especially for the weekends because there is usually a crowd gathered outside waiting whenever I drive by.  

My friend and I agreed to return again and soon!  We'd love to visit around the holidays as well.  There is something truly special about sipping tea here --I definitely recommend.
author: Vanessa G.

description: This place was unexpected and pretty charming. It is like being at grandma's house. Lots of breakable items on doilies and a pillow for everyone's back. Even the bathroom was dolled up. This is like playing tea party as a kid, but with food that is not imaginary. The service is outstanding, and the scones were really buttery and flaky. Took me a bit to figure out the sandwiches on the platter for high tea, but all in all it was a huge spread that left us full for the afternoon. Chicken salad was a favorite, but I thought it was just okay. The pear and Gorgonzola and the tea (apricot and chestnut) were excellent. The chestnut tea was almost like drinking maple syrup without the sweet. The salad was yummy-I liked that it wasn't dressed, but I didn't much care for the slaw-although my boyfriend liked it.
author: Carolyn H.

description: Amazing service and a really good selection of teas. I had a really good birthday breakfast here. Definitely looking forward to coming again
author: Kaylyn B.

description: It offers a different perspective than the high teas offered in the luxury hotels and far more delightful. The food was good--shepherd's pie, sandwiches and the tea variety. I chose this place for my birthday because of the reviews and it lives up to its reputation. Service was also attentive.
author: L G.

description: I've been coming to Lovejoy's for over 15 years and absolutely love the experience of having tea there. It's always a special treat when I get to introduce someone to Lovejoy's for the first time. Today was such a day. Our server was Lauren, who was fantastic. Lauren hit all the right notes: friendly, efficient, attentive and very genuinely interested in our satisfaction with our tea and our food. She went the extra mile to heat up our milk for our tea (as is our preference), and to bring us extra milk. We ordered a Queen's Tea to share and it was perfect. The quality of the food at Lovejoy's is always exceptional. I need the recipe for their delicious salad dressing; it's SO good!
author: Skyroad C.

description:
I know that you can't necessarily compare a Beamer to a Honda, but it's hard not to compare when I've been to the likes of the Sheraton Palace Hotel & Rotunda for tea service.  My work organized a tea lunch in celebration of International Women's Day.  Even at 11:30am on a Friday the place had a good amount of patrons.  Keep in mind it's small though so make reservations! 

This time around since I'm pregnant, my sandwich selections were very limited.  So I went with the cucumber and cream cheese, and a hummus and artichoke sandwich.  I went with a delicious light white strawberry tea.  We noticed how each tea cup set and pot were different.  Some of us got retro almost 50's like plain tea pots (me) and some got traditional Victorian looking ones.  I think I would've liked the consistency.  Lovejoy's provides an affordable tea lunch menu with different options with different price points, no wine here though.  

Our tea lunch option included a pot of tea, two sandwich choices (which turns into eight sandwich triangles total), shared salad and a scone.  I think they should've let each person choose more than just two sandwich options since you get bored of the flavors.  Though it's appreciated that they let their customers choose especially since some have dietary restrictions.  I didn't eat any of the salad.  My sandwiches could've used seasoning.  Cucumber and cream cheese was pretty standard, some mint to add more flavor would've been lovely.  At first I couldn't tell where my hummus sandwich was since it almost looked like some's tuna sandwich.  It was fine, but again, lacked any seasoning.  The scone had some small raisins in it and was moist.  I honestly think that was the favorite thing I ate there.  We all also got a small cookie to finish off our meal.  I thought the salad option was weird.  I would've appreciated fruit as I've always seen, especially since it's easier to divide portions of that with a group and just more sanitary (i.e. People mixing tongs).  

Service was good and I loved my tea and scone but that's about it.  The Sheraton Palace and Rotunda will be my benchmarks for awhile.  However, I've been to Secret Garden in Sunset before and I thought the menu was more impressive, but then again, back then I didn't have any dietary restrictions.
author: Cat C.

description: Recommended by a friend and came to check it out.  We had the Queen tea set & High tea set. The food was okay, but tea wasn't impressive. The place was cute and cozy. The mismatched tea cups and pots were fun too, but a few were quite worn - I understand that they might be trying to keep the antique and vintage look but teacups with chipped edges should not be allowed.
author: Marina M.

description:
So it's definitely further out from the city than I'm used to going to but it adds to the overall appeal. It's definitely a very quaint and cute tea shop versus a fancy or ritzy place. None of the tea sets match but are all very cute! Went with a big group and had a reservation but still had to wait ~10 mins to be seated. Other than that, service was great!

Ambiance: mainly female but more families here than any other afternoon tea room I've been to! Has a small town feel to it but mixed with eclectic SF details
Food: ordered the High Tea set, which came with two tea sandwiches, cole slaw, salad, scone (with amazing clotted cream and jam), and a cookie (small and meh), along with a bottomless tea.
author: Taryn Q.

description: I made a reservation online weeks before the actually Saturday morning and it is quite popping. This place opens up at 11am and it was packed. I had a gift certificate for queens tea for two and this was actually enough for four people. There is unlimited tea and there are enough litto sandwiches to satisfy us. For one Queens tea, you get to choose two sandwiches and it comes with crumpet, scone, fruit, salad and this litto piece of cake. My friend chose the tea but they were both fruity and I thought they were just ok. I am not really a tea person unless it is the boba. Overall it is a cute experience to do with friends for a special occasion. When you are inside, it looks so busy but it is because it used to be an antique shop.
author: Amy H.

description:
Not going to lie, this place is kind of strange. Imagine when you walk into your 92 year old grandma's house, and there are small chochtskies everywhere, and everything is kind of dated and has that senior citizen smell. 

You're actually not at your grandma's. You're at Lovejoy's.

Maybe I felt a little less magic because on my way to the bathroom I saw the "kitchen" and their tea sandwiches were being made out of Safeway bread. Maybe I was just in a bad mood that day?

Overall- food was decent. Tea was pretty good. It's a cute little area, and I did have fun with the Queens tea (aka pretending to be fancy), but not sure if I would come here again, mainly because of the environment.
author: Steph D.

description:
Cute little tea room on Church Street with classic tearoom decor and vintage furniture that make for a cozy ambiance. 

Menu has a wide variety of things to select from so you're not kept to a few set-menu options. You can opt for a full tea, or something less filling that includes finger sandwiches or pastries only. There are also other options such as salads, sandwiches, and even a ploughman's lunch option. 

Personally, I really like the dessert part of the afternoon tea experience, and with the full tea options here, you only get to select one item from a tray, such as a petit four or a cookie. I particularly like having a few options, which most other standard tearooms offer. 

Service is amazing, folks regularly check in on you and will refill your teapot about halfway through the meal. 

Pro-tip, it's a very small venue so reservations are hard to get, and they only take them via email or phone so definitely make sure to plan ahead.
author: Alison A.

description: It's a cutesy little place to go for a Sunday brunch. The service and ambiance was great. They have tea sandwiches that was surprisingly filling. Also, maybe it was because of the pot of tea refills that made us feel full. My friends and I each ordered our own sets which was waaaayyy more food than we anticipated. My friends had the Queen and Light Tea set. I had the High Tea and I honestly would've been okay with the Light Tea set. We reserved this place a week ahead on a Sunday and used up the two hour seating limit. Overall, a fun little place for a catch up sesh. We paid about $90 between the four of us with each of our tea sets. I suggest getting two Queen tea or High tea sets for 4 people instead of each of your own. Make sure to check out their "attic" across the street for some tea set goodies!
author: Angelie A.

description:
My girlfriends and I decided to try this place out for her birthday. I honestly don't recall anything that WOW'ed me. I have to say that I was a bit disappointed after trying this place. I've definitely had better tea time . I think this place was hyped up but I'm glad to have tried it at least once. 

I ordered the "High Tea for Two" w/ a black lavender tea. Again I was not really impressed with the tea. I couldn't taste nor smell the lavender even though I let it sit for a bit.  The sandwich selection wasn't to my liking but my friend and had two choices each so we decided to share a , cucumber & cream cheese, egg & onion, asparagus & chicken, and salmon & cream cheese. I mean you can go wrong with sandwiches, but I didn't finish  it at all. We had also scones that came with with jelly and cream.

I have to say the chicken & asparagus looked really weird, almost like it was avocado as it was a spread , and the egg  & onion was a bit too much too my liking, (a lot of onions).  The salad was ok, ( can't go wrong with that). There wasn't much that came with this "High Tea" package. 

Overall service was great, I recommend to at least try this place once, parking is easy but this place gets packed quick so make a reservation ahead of time as its very popular.  But I don't think I would come back again unless its a new seasonal menu.
author: Tiffany K.

description:
Some would say it's overpriced, but I get it- you pay for the ambience. That's not what the 3 stars is for. I used to love coming here with my mom, grandma, aunts and cousins for a ladies tea every spring. 

However, making reservations used to be a nightmare because calling in was a nightmare. They must have taken feedback because they upgraded to a third party reservation website. Great, right? WRONG.

The site charged me $1.50 without consent and another $1.50 to change my reservation less than 1 hour after my original booking.
