The decor was so cute and quaint and the service was extremely friendly and helpful! Most of the good tables were reserved for a special party, but they did have a couple open tables for walk-ins. It was a bit cramped since they try to accommodate so many people, which is why I am only giving four stars, but my mom and I are both pretty small so it didn't bother us too much. I really enjoyed my experience here and seeing as how I love going to tea, this was a great outing for a cheaper price than other tea parlors I have been to. 

Overall great experience and can't wait to go back!
author: Melissa B.

description:
The highest of 4-stars goes to Lovejoy's. 

As most have described, the atmosphere is a wonderful mix of mixed china and fantastic teas. The food is absolutely delicious and the tea is plentiful. I was certainly impressed by the variety of choices that Lovejoy's offered, in terms of both food and tea. 

The only reason I don't give LJ's a 5-star review is the $9.95/person minimum. This makes it difficult to go in for a quick cup of tea without making an afternoon of it. Also, seating ends at 5, so in order to maximize your experience, get there with plenty of time to spare. 

If you haven't checked out Lovejoy's, take an hour or two out of your day and make a stop there.
author: Tom A.

description:
The best in food, tea, and ambience as far as high tea in the Bay Area goes.

Everyone usually gets the high tea -- endless pot of tea, choice of a couple of sandwiches, bit of salad, etc.

But if you go one step higher in the menu, you get a little more food for a few more bucks.
author: Wella L.

description:
*Sigh* My cozy, eclectic hideaway.

Layered doily tablecloths, mismatched utensils, and antique photographs occupy every nook and cranny of this English-style teahouse.  It is the perfect introduction to an afternoon abundant with delicious food, comforting tea, and good conversation.  

My boyfriend and I tend to go for the High Tea for Two.  For about $35, we each get coleslaw, salad, a choice of two sandwiches, scones, cookies, and our own individual pots of bottomless tea.  The pear and stilton sandwich is my favorite, but if you eat anything make sure you try the scones!  

My boyfriend, who is more of the coffee type, enjoys the Yorkshire Gold tea.  I have tried both the pumpkin spice and cha cha cha teas and like them as well.  

We have had the same server on both of our visits.  She has been very good about explaining the menu layout and recommending items.  Our teapots always stay hot and full.  Service is attentive without being invasive.  

Lovejoy's is the perfect place to enjoy some simple food over a nice pot of tea and good company.  I look forward to trying out more teas in the visits to come!
author: Renee M.

description:
Think Alice in Wonderland's or Mary Poppin's tea.  This is a perfect spot for a fun event.  One of us was turning 60, another was turning 65, but the place was full of younger folk, too, evidently celebrating, perhaps engagements.  Lots of eye candy decorates the room - china and linens.

Reservations were no problem (and necessary).  Oddly enough, parking was not a problem.  Once you are there, settle in for a good long time. The staff was wonderful, attentive, accomodating and informative!

The five of us had the Queen's Tea - a feast.  Be sure to tell the staff if there is a birthday in the group so they can put a candle in the petit four (too bad I am not one for almond paste).  I suggest that each guest order a different sandwich filling and then share around the table.  Same with the tea, get different ones and share, being sure to ask for hot water refills.  

Believe everyone about the scones!  I couldn't resist Devonshire cream AND lemon curd on them PLUS buttering the crumpet (It WAS my birthday.)  Perhaps we should have brought a bottle of bubbly with us - corkage is reasonable.  On the other hand, we were stuffed and loggy with tea.  Tea can be quite stimulating - the room rings with conversation.

Sometime that's more fun than a bar crawl, ladies.  BTDTBTT.
author: Francesca G.

description:
I love doing girly things with my girlfriends and this was quite a treat for my bday! 

I've been to Lisa's Tea Treasures in Campbell and enjoyed the atmosphere there. Outside of work, I don't go to SF much, so it's great to find an unique place worth driving out to.  Parking may be a bit of a pain though, unless you are get lucky on one of the side streets with no meters. 

I sure felt like royalty here with the 'Reserved for Royalty' sign and our attentive wait staff. Everyone ordered the Queen's Tea special, which was more than enough food to feast on. I loved all the sandwiches, especially the curry sandwich special they served that day. The scones went well with the different preserves and lemon curd. The petite four bites were a bit too sweet for my taste, it looked too good to eat. 

Great atmosphere, delicious high tea treats, and wonderful company! 

I will be back for another special occasion.  Be sure to make reservations, this place is always packed!
author: Caroline S.

description: Love this place, and the staff, tea, and sandwiches just make me wanna keep coming back! The shepards pie is also quite tasty, and can be shared between two to three people.
author: Mars F.

description: This place has nice decor! But minus 1 star for sandwiches, bread is hard. Teas are alright! , typical!
author: Pia L.

description: Quite nice little tea room. Great to go for high tea! The Yorkshire Gold is amazing and the shepherds pie is well proper British! Go!
author: Jeremy H.

description:
Yum!!  The best cream tea I've had in America!

My friends were also very pleased with their Savory Tea and crumpets.

Only drawback is that it's VERY crowded and a little noisy depending on what sort of groups are there (we had a children's birthday party and a baby shower in addition to other customers), which doesn't really make it the perfect place to linger over your bottomless pot of tea.  We still had a great time, and the quality of the food and the cheerful attitude of all of the staff made up for the crowd.  In spite of all the patrons, the service was very good - hardly any wait and never a cold pot of tea.  Ambiance and china were good.  

If you want to make sure you can get a table, call for a reservation very far in advance, especially on the weekends.  We didn't call early enough to get a reservation, but fortunately, they are pretty able to accommodate small groups of walk-ins.  Our wait was about 20 mins., and it passed very quickly as we browsed in their cute shop across the street.

I hope to go back to Lovejoy's when we're in SF next - just hope to be able to plan it at a time when they're not as busy.
author: Ashley W.

description:
Kind of new to the whole tea thing, I wasn't sure what to expect. I was super excited though, and definitely not disappointed. It definitely has a cozy feel to it, so I wouldn't imagine it would be able to accommodate huge groups. I think the mismatched furniture and silverware adds a nice touch to the atmosphere. 

The sandwiches were really good! We had the high tea for two and were rather full by the end. We got the cucumber sandwich, roast beef with horseradish, salmon with cream cheese and stilton and pear (love!). The warm scones were delicious and the dressing for the salad was lovely. Not the hugest fan of the coleslaw, probably because of mint? in it. I don't know. And having just come from Crown and Crumpet, I can say that I prefer Lovejoys because of the sandwich selections.
author: Deanna L.

description:
My girl Ness first introduced me to this spot on 16th and Church in the city, and I've have tried to make it a monthly routine ever since. I know, I know. I used to be just like you. Laughing in a bad English accent, "Tea and crumpets with the Queen?" Pshhh. And we all know "cucumber sandwhiches wtih the sides cut off," are frowned upon by heffers far and wide. But let me tell you, this ain't your grandmother's tea party.

The place is a cozy, yet eclectic corner tea house. Complete with mix matched China, vintage wall hangings, and crochet doilies. The waitresses are all very pleasant and very knowledgeable of the teas, food, and what goes good with what. And while it's a rather noisy establishment, cell phones are not allowed so please take ur loud ass outside when ur T-Pain ringtone goes off.

OK, now for the food. OMG. I'm getting hungry just thinking about it. While it's no House of Prime Rib, I can honestly say that I've NEVER left this place still hungry - and I CAN GRUB. Me and Ness usually get "High Tea for Two," and I usually end up finishing whatever she leaves behind. This includes, salad, cole slaw, 2 sandwhiches of our choice (each, so 4 in all), 2 scones, sugar cookies, and 2 bottomless pots of tea. My fave combo is bay shrimp and mayo, and either chicken and asparagus or egg and onion with passion fruit tea. And seriously, the "devonshire cream," aka butter from the Gods is so good on top of a warm scone I'm thinking about stealing it next time. Mind u, they also have savory side dishes like sausage rolls, shepards pie, quiches, and puff pastries filled with things like curried chicken.

Lovejoy's Tea Room is the quintessential spot for a bridal/baby shower but any day (especially sunny, warm Sundays!) is a good day for tea!
author: Tor E.

description:
I came here with a friend and we had high tea for 2. We had the darjeeling and the china rose petal teas. The china rose petal was amazing--light but also unique and flavorful. Its probably my all time favorite tea so far! The darjeeling was ok, I'd probably go with something else next time. You get a generous portion of 2 sandwiches for each person (that's 8 triangles per person!) which I believe is more than other high tea places. I wish we could get more than 2 kinds of different sandwiches given that you actually get 8 pieces, but I understand that it would complicate things in the kitchen. We had the bay shrimp and mayo, salmon and cream cheese, chicken apple walnut and the daily special (can't remember off the top of my head), which were all very very good. The scone was also very good, though I usually like mine a little fluffier. The reason I give it four stars is because they give a lot of greens as filler, which is pretty tasteless. I also wasn't a huge fan of the cabbage salad. I just don't think these 2 things go very well with a tea service, but that's just my opinion. For $20 a person, I'd rather have more tea biscuits or petit fours.

The tea room is a little bit small/cramped and our table was very tiny. I was a little scared of knocking something over. The same goes for the Lovejoy's tea shop across the street, though the surrounding neighborhood is very cute. Service was very good. The bathroom was very clean and was decorated nicely (lots of mirrors-haha)! Parking can be a little difficult if you come here at a busy time.

Overall, I had a very good experience and I would definitely come back if in the area. However, I do prefer Tyme for Tea in Fremont, which is similar in price, but is a little easier to get to and superior in taste in my opinion.
author: Janet N.

description: Having tried a couple of tea rooms in the city, I'd say this is by far my favorite!  The decor is so quaint and delightful!  Makes me wanna speak British for a while! Definitely recommend reservations unless it's a week day. Their sandwiches and scones are delicious!  I love the English double devon cream.  Lovejoy's provides a couple of hours where you can immerse in a world where you can just catch up with some girlfriends and unwind.  Oh yea, pretty easy to find parking on weekdays but there is a 2 hour limit and the meter maids are always around!  Can't wait for my next tea time!
author: Chrisy C.

description: Absolutely the tops for a high tea experience. The decoration is surpassed only by the teas and nibbles. Even my gruff cowboy loved it.
author: Anne S.

description:
LOVE.THIS.PLACE!  Everything about it!  From decor to their food!  I've been here twice.  My absolute favorite is the High Tea for Two in which you can add an additional person for $17.99!  Since you can pick 4 different kinds of sandwiches, (6 if you add an additional person) my grandma, mom and I got the smoked salmon and cream cheese, roastbeef, bay shrimp and mayonnaise, cream cheese and green apple, chicken apple walnut salad and smoked turkey and dijon mustard!  My ultimate favorite was the bay shrimp and mayonnaise.

You can pick 2 kinds of tea (3 teas for three people).  We ordered the Vanilla Roobios, China Rose Petal and Passion Fruit which was by far my favorite.  I must say that they're NOT greedy with their tea.  It comes in a big teapot and the waiters are constantly refilling it.  All you can drink tea!  

And omg, their scones!  I never liked them until I tasted Lovejoys' scones.  It comes with the High Tea for Two by the way.  It's warm and soft with raisins mixed in.  Once you spread the preserves and double devon cream, omg...it's ON!!  So delicious!  

The decor is super cute especially the utensils, teacups, teapots and plates.  As if you were at your grandmother's house.  So girly.  However, it can get a bit squishy when you try to get to your table.  Be careful when you walk between tables.  You might break something!  

The waiters are very nice.  I also love how they come to your table and offer you little dessert pastries.  It's not free but it's quite delicious.

Safe area but parking might be hard to find.
author: Kanani N.

description:
I've been dying to have a tea party since Jennifer C. told me about her experience in Seattle.  Does this make me an old English lady?  Cuz i totally enjoyed myself eating finger sandwiches, snacking on crumpets and scones, all the while sipping tea.  Yes, I had my pinky up a few times. Is there any other way to drink english tea?

The interior is quite antiquated.  I was waiting for the smell of mothballs to invade my nostrils, but it never did.  There are little knick knacks everywhere.  Antique galore might be a better phrase to describe this place.  I almost felt like i was invading an old lady's hang out spot.  

Jennifer C and I had High Tea for 2 + an order of crumpets.  The scones were super fresh and awesome... i could eat those forever.  The sandwiches were good but not anything special.  I enjoyed the tea.  We had the Tea Room Blend (black tea) and the Passion Fruit Black Tea.  

Other than that, everything was good.  I didn't find this place super special or super awesome.  It was my first high tea experience and i'm going to continue finding places to have my tea.  However, I now feel a lot more sophisticated now that I've done this.  I am a proper gentleman now.  My next goal is to be knighted.  Sir Aaron Gong has a nice ring to it doesn't it?
author: Aaron G.

description: The love joy tea room is a treasure in Noe Valley. It's a lovely place to catch up with your friends, relax and take in the elegance of the decor. The tea is also delicious. I recommend the chocolate tea and the pomegranate green tea.
author: Sima B.

description: I believe their kitchen closes in the late afternoon because when we went there late afternoon on a weekend, the staff told us that the kitchen was already closed and that we can only order tea and the baked goods on display. Their tea on its own without milk or sugar is excellent and their scones are to die for!  The staff was very accommodating even gave my friend's 2 yr old her own cup and saucer. Will definitely go back to try their tea sandwiches!
author: Janis P.

description:
Another great recommendation from  "Check Please". The minute you enter this place, you instantly step into a cute little England cottage.  We were fortunate enough to be seated at a table with sofa. The red phone booth was next to us.  It was cozy. Our waitress was attentive and kept refilling water for our tea. We ordered the Queen tea set that came with a good selection of sandwiches, scone and salad. It also has a wide selection of non flavored tea which I prefer.  Our waitress was very knowledgeable about the tea was patience explaining to us.  

This place seems to be more popular with female patrons hosting birthday party and bridal shower. You don't' have to wait for any special events. Just come enjoy the ambience. Bring a few friends to catch up or a simply a good spot to relax after a day of walking in the city.  Make sure you have a late dinner as we were pretty full after the meal at 3pm
author: Angie W.

description:
Guys don't be scared of Lovejoy's Tea Room. Just man up and go in there and order the High Tea!( hehehe)

But seriously, this place is perfect if you want to spend an afternoon conversing with friends over some tea and good food. We ordered High Tea for two and the servers were great in helping us to choose through the selection of teas and sandwiches available. The tea room blend was my favorite from the four my group ordered. I added a splash of milk and a spoonful of sugar and it was almost like a chai tea, but lighter with a slightly bitter taste that wasn't bad. And the little sandwiches were great! The combinations of sandwiches may sound a bit strange, but they are all rather yummy. Like who puts Oranges with cream cheese in sandwich?! Genius, I tell you! Make sure you make reservations because this place can get packed. I can't wait to go back. eww that rhymed.
author: Theresa D.

description: Great quality food and tea, nice environment, and very attentive service. It took a couple weeks to get a reservation, but it was so worth the wait!
author: Julie B.

description:
Super Unpretentious Girlie Fun!

I attended a baby shower here and we had a fabulous time! I loved the jasmine tea blossom! I have never had so much tea in my entire life all at once. I couldn't stop myself because it was so fresh and tasty! 

The finger sandwiches were delectable and perfect little bites to soak up all the tea I drank...haha! I love the mismatched cups and saucers....so adorable! It's a very relaxed atmosphere! The waitstaff is super helpful!

It was pretty crowded, so I'm sure reservations are a must and get there early because parking is a bitch in the city!
author: Karen C.

description:
It was a girl's day out so we had tea at Lovejoy's. 

They open on the dot at 11 am. Thank goodness we had reservations. Everyone that showed up seemed to have had them too. 

We all loved the antique plates and tea pots. Not one piece of silverware or dinnerware was the same! The crumpets with lemon curd were so delicious! And all the tea we sampled were very different but yummy. The sandwiches were bite-size and delectable. 

It's definitely a fun spot for ladies to hangout, not so much for guys. And they are very accommodating to groups. Lovejoy's was very enjoyable. We'd do it again if we have the chance.
author: Diana C.

description: Great service, the sandwiches were ok but the spreads and the pastries were DELICIOUS. Try to come and get a window seat, it's so pleasant! :)
author: Betty W.

description:
I want to say a BIG HAPPY BDAY TO COCO!! What a great reason to write my 500th review. 

Perfect place to have afternoon tea and for any celebration. We came on Saturday to have Tea with Caroline for her Bday. I suggest you call to make a reservation since they place books up fast. We all end up ordering the Queen's Tea. We end up sharing all the small sammies, sip our flavors teas, had scones with the lemon curd and devon cream. YUM! Plus fruit and a petite four. My goodness did we eat. Don't forget the crumpets too. Plus love how all of the food came out and all so cute and decorative. 

The place is deck out in cuteness and girly items. Having tea with friends and catching up is the best. Plus it gave me a sense of times that was slower and simpler. Which was nice. 

Had a wonderful time and so love to do it again.
author: Donna Y.

description:
This is a really cute place :) Two of my friends and I came here and got seated in the corner. The sign said "Reserved for the queens" or something to that effect. Anyway, we ordered crumpets (to try, not knowing what they were.) They came with very yummy lemon curd. I don't think I cared for the crumpets themselves that much.

Ooh, and vanilla rooibos tea... mmm. Sooo good!
Scones were also good.
Tea sandwiches - we chose pear/stilton, chicken-apple-walnut and salmon mousse. I think the last one was the daily special, but I forget what it was. All were pretty good!

Three of us shared a tea for two and we were quite full by the end of the meal... Was kinda surprising. Anyway this is a really cute place with good food :)
author: Clarissa L.

description:
Lovejoy's is so sweet and lovely. It was especially nice when I visited because I was feeling a bit off and having a bad day. My trip to LJ's turned my whole day around. I had the Sweet Tea, which included a bottomless pot of whatever type of tea you desired, plus a few petite foures to go with. Since I wasn't feeling my best I had a pot of green tea with mint. It was good and it lifted my spirits. I highly recommend trying Lovejoy's for yourself in great company. It is unique tea-lover's experience without all the frills of high tea.  

Oh, did I mention that EVERYTHING is on sale?! If you like the pot your tea was brewed in or the cup you are sipping out of... why not purchase it. I thought that was a nifty idea.
author: Nichole P.

description: Wonderfully quaint tea room. The tea was flowing, food delicious and it was all reasonably priced. We had such a fun time I am planning another visit in the new year.
author: Lindsay J.

description: Good tea and food. Be on time for your reservation because the 2 hour time limit is real!
author: T S.

description:
Attentive service and phenomenal food.  I just can't say enough good things about Lovejoys.  

I enjoyed afternoon tea here for my birthday on August 18th. 

This time I tried the quiche which was cheesy and rich and flavorful.  I highly recommend it.  The pear and stilton, and the roast beef and horseradish sandwiches were absolutely delicious as well.  It was a lovely afternoon.
author: Desiree A.

description:
awesome scones, tea, and sandwiches.  we've been coming here for 6 or 7 years.  best afternoon tea place in SF - scones are warm and moist, sandwiches are tasty.  get the egg and onion and the bay shrimp and mayonnaise sandwiches.

the salad that comes with the teas is not interesting and not necessary.  i think they should just skip that.
author: Yin L.

description: My family and I had a pleasant dining experience,  but the food was mediocre. Service was friendly and the ambience was home like.  The four of us shared the quiche,  hight tea for two, and another order of scones.  The quiche was okay;  savory and a little fever with egg  cheese and potatoes.  Each high tea cubes with a scone, two sandwiches,  salad, coleslaw,  and a tea biscuit.  The scones were sublime and as large as hamburger buns; this is the best feature.  The sandwiches were too tiny and nothing special as the turkey and ham meats are the sky deli meats you get from a grocery store.  I kid you not: the sandwiches are the size of two McDonald's chicken nuggets. The white peach tea was very tasty.  The black vanilla lavender is actually very pleasant too and was soothing and not at all perfume.
author: Lorenzo V.

description: First high tea experience.  The bride invited her bridal party to this place for cucumber sandwiches sans the crust, tea, freshly made crumpets, buttery cookies and petit fours.  Delicious food, teacups with character, and a wonderful venue for a get together.  Make reservations and be prepared to wait when you arrive.
author: Cynthia C.

description:
I felt under=dress here, but don't feel like you will get the boot, the owner is very welcoming and friendly, no need to worry about the snootiness us Brits are known for (some of us, no offense your Majesty). I joined my mother and my aunts here for a high tea, the menu is very vegetarian friendly, I loved the hummus and the toast bites (even though when I posted a picture of it on FB I was getting a carb lecture from one of my friends -- its all good) 

Make reservations, I'm not sure about the walk ins, my mother is planning to bring her friends here for a get together, she talked to the owner because one of her friends is in a wheelchair, the place is wheelchair accessible, but if you have a friend in a wheelchair, it's best to call ahead of time to let them know, they will make sure to give you a space up in the front. 

Cheerio! enjoy your spot of tea loves
author: Peta C.

description: A really nice place to relax and have some tea. Feels like an English Tea house in London.
author: Jean Y.

description:
Let me first start by saying this is not the type of place I would usually go to, but it was good!   My girlfriend was given a gift certificate to this place, so we thought we would have a Sunday brunch there.  We had "High Tea" the bite sized smoked salmon sandwiches were great!  We also had apple-cranberry-nut sandwiches, and they where great!  Service was good, food was good, and prices are good.  The scones were even warm! The jam even tasted like it was home-made!  It went great with the tea.  The only thing they where missing there, was my Grandma! ha ha!  They were busy, but we never felt rushed.  The little old lady that waited on us really was sweet.  We're glad we stopped by!

It really has the charm of my Grandma's old home back in the Mid-West.  

Well done...

Perfect place to take Mom, Grandma, or the girlfriend!
author: C J.

description: Best blueberry scone I have ever had in my life, and I have lived in many cities. Crispy and buttery with perfectly cooked blueberries. High tea is served here. I had Queen's tea. It's more than enough food and variety. Very tasty sandwiches, rich cookies and crumpets, ridiculously good scones, to die for lemon curd, and super sweet fruit. Great tea selection and quality. Ambiance is cute and cozy. Take a friend or family member at least once. It makes for a memorable experience.
author: Janet J.

description:
What a wonderful time!  My daughter loves tea, so I took her on a bit of an adventure last Friday, to Lovejoy's.  My husband and I had seen a segment of "Eye on the Bay" highlighting Lovejoy's and immediately thought of taking my daughter there.
We traveled from Walnut Creek on BART, getting off at Powell station.  From there we jumped on Muni "J" outbound line.  There is a stop right at Lovejoy's.
I will tell you I made a reservation for our visit.  I would definitely recommend doing that.  While we were dining, I heard staff telling people there would be an hour wait.
(I did see the group come back and hour later!)
My daughter and I each ordered "high tea", discussing what sandwiches we each wanted so we would share items we liked.  The staff was very friendly and helpful.  We ordered one type of tea during lunch and a different one to have with our dessert. There was plenty of food, all fresh and attractive.  I will go back again, although if I am sharing with someone, I don't think I would order 2 high teas.  There was quite a bit of food for 2 of us.
We were kept entertained by looking at all the "stuff" around us.  There was a lot to see.  
The clientele was mainly women with a few gents thrown in.

After we had consumed our lunch, which took a good 2 hours, we walked across the street to Lovejoy's store where you can purchase tea and all kinds of tea related goods.  

The inbound Muni "J" stops right in front of the tea room, so it was extremely convenient.

We will return and bring others.  I have started to spread the word!
author: Carol H.

description:
I was here for a bachelorette party with 6 girls.  The sandwiches and tea were delicious, there was a huge selection to choose from on the menu.  I've also done the afternoon tea at the Fairmont which was much more frou frou, I felt like I should have worn a big hat just to eat there.  This place, on the other hand, was a much more casual atmosphere.  They had cute knick knack tea related memorabilia around that were really cute.  

As for the food, the sandwiches were delicious and the size was about what I expected.  After all, they are crumpet finger foods.  Although, there was a funny moment when both my cousin and I noticed on our way back from the bathroom that they were just using Safeway Select bread for the sandwiches.  I guess it's what's in it that counts because it was still delicious.  Also, at the end of your tea, they also give you a coupon to use at their cute gift/antique shop across the street. 

My only criticism of this place is they are very stringent with the time.  Our reservations was at 11am, which is when they opened.  We arrived there are 10:45am and were waiting for them to open the doors.  While we were waiting, there was also a baby shower party waiting.  At this point, there was a huge crowd of people outside but even so, they still wouldn't let us come in from the cold to be seated a little early.  Then, at the end, our 2 hour limit was up and as we were chatting, our waitress came and said nicely, "this is your 15 min warning because your 2 hours is coming up soon, thank you."  I was a little taken aback because even though she was very  nice about it, calling it a warning didn't help. 

However, I would come here again, tho never with a guy- he would never get enough to eat.  I'm better off staying home and making him multiple regular non crumpet sandwiches.
author: Krystal C.

description:
I brought my daughter and several of her little friends to Lovejoy's to celebrate my daughter's birthday.  The five of them had a ball!  The hostess (sorry I forgot your name) and Mara our waitress were simply fantastic! The hostess was super nice to us when we arrived a bit late (wrangling ten year old girls is not just a job, its an adventure) I did call and let her know that we were fast and furiously on our way from the East Bay and to please not give away our table.  Mara was nice and friendly and explained everything to us and offered some nice suggestions for the birthday girl and her entourage.  She even helped us take some really cute photos of ourselves in hats and crowns.

The young ladies had the Wee Tea, which is perfect for those 10 and under. Hot chocolate with plenty of whipped cream, warm scone, choice of one tea sandwich assorted fruit and a lollipop all arrived on pretty tiered serving trays.  Kids really like the lemon curd and Devonshire cream, I would strongly suggest adding one or both of these to the Wee Tea.  The kids did complain that they wished they had more sandwiches (cream cheese and mandarin orange and tried and true cream cheese and cucumber) to eat with their Wee Tea.  The sandwiches are incredibly small. The kids were only a little bit hungry afterward, but most of the kids I know seem to have tapeworms, a hollow leg or both, especially when it comes to food consumption.  So I am not surprised that they were still hungry.

 I had the Queens Tea with ham and pesto sandwiches and chicken apple walnut sandwiches.  I will rave about the bottomless tea, the scone, crumpets. The sandwiches again, were extremely small and the sandwich bread was dry, almost stale. Also, I could barely taste the pesto on my ham and pesto sandwiches.

The Decor was very charming.  Everything is mismatched so do not be startled by this and if you want brand new everything and matchy-matchy, go else where.  Everything is worn and cozy and comfortable. 
The kids loved the china mosaic that was on the floor just inside the front door. 

Lovejoy's a great experience for my daughter and her friends.  The laughed and giggled and nibbled snacks and got the chance to play proper English ladies. A great time was had by all. This was definitely a birthday my daughter will remember for years to come!
author: Mary P.

description:
I officially love high tea. 

It was really an experience coming here. I loved the atmosphere and the service was great. It was a little crowded, but it's obvious why. I went with my friend and fellow yelper Shirley W. and another friend, so I don't need to describe the tea and food again, but it was excellent! My favorites were the mango tea, and turkey with cranberry and egg with onion sandwiches. 

Definitely a ditto on the bathroom situation. But I would still come back too!
author: Nancy H.

description:
Food: I love this place! We had a going away "tea party" for my best friend. we ordered a bunch of stuff and snacked on tea sandwiches, scones, petit fours, salad, and fresh fruit. The food here isn't anything super amazing but it is nice to snack on. Tea was good as well. This is a fun place to come with your girlfriends!

Price: Pretty expensive. At least $20 or so a person.

Service: Friendly

Atmosphere: Loved the atmosphere in here. Decorations are almost all antique and you feel like your in grandma's house!

Location: Located on Church. You can take the J here.
author: Miss H K.

description:
I came here with a couple friends for tea on a Saturday afternoon. I made reservations in advance which was pretty easy. I called and had to leave a message. They called me back right away and let me know the time I wanted was not available but let me know when they did have an opening. When we came for tea we were a little late because of traffic and trying to find parking (which wasn't too bad) and wasn't given a hard time about coming late which was nice. I had the queen's tea. The warm scone were awesome and the toasted crumpet was pretty good but the lemon curd was super runny and not really that great. The tea sandwiches were also pretty good. You can tell they were super fresh. Their tea sandwich selection was great... so many tea sandwiches to chose from. You get your choice of any two to go with your tea. I liked being able to pick your own sandwiches. I did not like only getting two choices though. Usually at other tea places I would get four tea sandwiches (one piece of each) plus savory pastries, so the two tea sandwiches (four pieces of each) and no savory pastries to go with, it seemed a little redundant after a while. If I come here again I will be sure to suggest we all get different sandwiches and trade some pieces so we all get some more variety which would solve the problem... though I was a little disappointed that they didn't already have something like that built into the menu. They also served salad and coleslaw with the tea. With the queen's tea I also got a choice of petite four which they had 3 or 4 different flavors or a frosted rice krispy treat. I chose the rice krispy treat which was good. It was nice to get the choice. The tea selection was pretty low... not too much variety. They did keep filling up our tea pots though which kept the tea nice and warm and full! 

Speaking of warm though... that place was so warm and stuffy! It was so uncomfortable. I was sweating, trying to enjoy my warm tea, quickly losing my appetite, feeling dirty and sticky from the runny lemon curd with only one smallish paper napkin to try and wipe up all the sticky lemon curd from my fingers while trying to protect my lap from the same fate as my sticky fingers. Bleh! It wasn't even that hot outside... maybe in the mid 70s outside.

The service was alright. Not really the pleasant over the top politeness I have come to expect from tea services. Also, toward the end of tea they came up to us with the check and let us know that there will be another party coming to take our table. This has never happened to me before in all my life. Disappointing because I do like to enjoy my tea service leisurely as it should be had. 

Overall, I was not too impressed with this place. If I do come back it will definitely be a strictly winter/fall tea stop.
author: Christina P.

description: You would think in San Francisco, gay men would not be a shocker to many. I came in here with my friend who was visiting from the UK for some tea. The first step we took in here, you'd think we were dressed as gangsters! Everyone was starring at us, not quite giving us bad looks..but might as well have been. The employees didn't have the best attitude and were almost rushing us. Food and tea were lovely, but it wasn't the best customer service.
author: William M.

description: What's not to love about tiny sandwiches and pretending to be the Queen of England? The biscuits and butter or "crumpets and clotted cream," as the Queen would say, are scrumptious and I think even Hercule Poirot would love this joint. It's pricey, but worth it if you want to do something "different" with people who have a sense of humor and a royal palate.
author: Nancy L.

description:
Tea rooms range from the opulent such as those at the grand hotels or understated and cuddly, like Lovejoy's. Might I also add that there's a rather large price difference; hotel high tea could set you back about $40+ per person, but at Lovejoy's, the most indulgent tea service is a mere $24.95. 

This small tea room is oh so darling, with it's haphazard decor of mismatched tablecloths and grandma's attic tea implements. The service is warm and friendly, with a wonderfully varied menu of good quality teas and yummy sandwiches. The scones were flaky and flavorful, served with Double Devon cream and preserves...just as they should be. The hot chocolate for my girls came out in an adorable little pitcher with whipped cream on the side in a smaller pitcher. And the petit fours were in the shape of hats.

Cute, Quaint and utterly Fabulous...especially for a girls' afternoon, discussing the finer points of gymnastics camp and soothing the jitters of a newly hatched Kindergartener.
author: Virg Y.

description:
The place itself is ok. The tea sets are really cute and the tea was good. 

However, I've been to many tea places and this one rates very low in my book. The  quality of the food is mediocre. The "scones" seem to be right out of the box and are in fact biscuit mix not actual scones. The sandwiches are pretty tasteless. My most recent tea place was in the Outer Sunset where they make their own loaves, the quality of the food was top notch and they actually made "scones" from scratches. Lovejoy is solely relying on their reputation from loyal customers but the quality lacks behind what they serve. Not worth the price at all.
author: Flo A.

description:
Went here for the first time today.  My girlfriend from high school was visiting from out of town and we had been talking about having high tea.  After much searching and disappointment that The Four Seasons Hotels and the Ritz-Carlton Hotels have discontinued their tea service, we found this place on Yelp.

We were half an hour late (boyfriends are slow) but lucky one person in our party was only 5 minutes late and saved the table for us.  She said they were very nice and didn't harass her about the rest of her party not showing up.

I had the Queen's Tea with English Breakfast tea and cucumber and turkey sandwiches.  The tea arrived first and after waiting anxiously for it to seep, I poured myself a cup.  It was delicious, but I am not a tea connoisseur.  Then arrived the food, on a three tiered platter.  The top tier was the fresh fruit, next the scone, biscuit, jam, lemon stuff, and the devon cream, the bottom tier had the sandwiches, cole slaw, and greens.

To be frank, when I first looked at it I thought they kind of skimped out on the fruit, but I was stuffed by the end of my meal, so really they are smarter than me!

After having some fruit, I decided to try the scone.  I first tried the devon cream...and that is when I realized that I loved this place!  If I had a lover, forget the whipped cream or chocolate sauce, this is what I'd cover his body with and lick off!!!  I could not get enough of it and I think this was my favorite item here.  Of course the jam and lemon stuff was good too, but I cannot describe my devotion to devon cream now.

The sandwiches were of course delicious and...dainty, delicate?  FUN!  I am not a super girlie girl.  My friend and I decided to put dresses on for the special occasion and I felt like a streetwalker even though my dress is conservative, but that is how rarely I wear things that don't have legs.  But this place played into my feminine side without me feeling awkward about it.  So yes, it's frilly and kitsch, but it works for this place.

A little while later came my fresh crumpet.  We decided crumpets are a pancake-english muffin hybrid, a puffin. Delicious, but I just wanted to get back to my scone and devon cream to be honest.

Lastly when we were done, we had our petite fours.  Which apparently I didn't really experience because I got the dark chocolate truffle with dried apricot.  But it was so cute and I love dark chocolate.  Petite fours are candy-sized, individually glazed pieces of cake. (My friend went to culinary school)

I completely want to return, but will probably only get the High Tea or even just the Light Tea next time.  The Queen's Tea was fantastic for the first time, so you get the entire experience and learn what you like.  But I personally didn't really like the cole slaw (I'm too American and eating it made me want ribs or something) and I was too full to even consider wasting space on a salad!

So if you go, invite me?
author: Monique H.

description:
This is probably one of the most eclectic places I have been to! With its mismatched everything and most adorable decorations, Lovejoy's is a perfect place for any occasion, even if its just a lunch on a regular Saturday.

I was treated to a Queens tea here and boy did I feel like a Queen.  Two sandwiches for each person, meaning I got to try 4!  The special of the turkey and cranberry was so delicious and my favorite out of all the ones I tried.  And the scones, the scones were just so yummy.  They were not dry like many scones you taste, but warm (even after they had been sitting on our table for a while) and much more moist than many others.  Plus the strawberry jam made the scone even better!  The crumpets were also quite tasty but the lemon curd really made the crumpet amazing.  Finally the petite fours (or however you spell them) just topped it off!

The whole experience was delightful.  The staff was more than helpful, nice and I just really enjoyed the whole experience!
author: Cara D.

description: SUCH a sweet little place. My friend suggested this for another friend's birthday celebration. We had a reservation for four in this adorably cozy place filled with couches, comfy tables, soft linens and a cozy fireplace! They have mismatched tea cups and teapots with a great menu of tea and my favorite-food! They have great and extensive tea service menu options that come with a bottomless pot of tea. Definitely worth a try--you'll definitely com back!
author: Erica S.

description:
This place is quite an experience. I highly recommend checking it out.

I think coming here too often would just make my head explode. So much frill, cutesy, princessy British stuff to look at here.

But boy is the food good and the tea tasty.
author: X O.

description:
I've been meaning to go here for years and today was the day. Why did I wait so long? This is a wonderful experience. The Earl Grey was the best I've ever had, the food (salad and scones) was 5 star deelish. The servers enjoy working here and sharing this unique spot, you can tell. 
It feels like you've entered a sanctuary. Parking is easy. 
Make a reservation, it is worth the planning!
author: Aquableu C.

description:
The best place for afternoon tea. I've been here more times than I can count and every time I've had great service, great snacks and bottomless pots of tea. The scones with devonshire cream are absolutely perfect with any of their tea selections. I love their decor, the mismatched china, cuckoo clocks and random frames on the wall make this place feel like a grandmother's place- very cozy. 

I've been to other tea houses in the area and always end up back of Lovejoy's after being disappointed elsewhere. This place is very popular, make a reservation. They will make every effort to seat you without one but expect to wait.
author: L M.

description:
I love tea parties! jk. I love tea and pastries.  I took the best friend and her beau and one of my guy friends to this spot.  I feel bad for the guys because they definitely looked out of place.  Then again, we were out of place dressed in jeans and coats and being Asian.

We were starving and without a reservation we waited such a long time (45 min to an hour) for a table.  There were tea parties going around near us.  Book clubs.  Little girls vomiting after eating too much...

After getting seated, we ordered 3 high teas and one shephard's pie. I was surprisingly full afterwards.  That feeling only lasted about 1 hour then i was hungry again. haha.  

The overall experience would have been better if:
1. we had a reservation
2. we had eaten before hand

Despite my review, I would come here again for the decor and menu.  Most high tea places look a little intimidating, but this place is definitely homey and worth trying out.
author: Jasmine A.

description:
Excellent!

This place is really cute and reasonable price for being a tea room. The sandwiches are good and so are the scones. The crumpets were just alright. Flavored black teas were good (Passion Fruit) and the flavored green tea-- not so much. The petit fours looked really cute. Service was also excellent. Also had good hot chocolate. Cute bathroom too!
author: Lisa T.

description:
This tea house sells the most elegant and high quality teas I have ever seen. You can definitely tell the difference between normal store bough earl grey tea, and Lovejoys quality Earl grey tea. There's just that big difference in taste that you can differentiate. 

This place also sells great quality made shepherds pie, and tiny delicious pastries to go along with your tea.
author: Saleem C.

description: Best of the best for authentic and exceptionally tasty high tea in San Francisco.  The staff is amazing, perfect ambiance and this place is a family celebration tradition.  I am almost glad I live across the city because if I lived in the hood, I would be here everyday probably.
author: Jennie M.

description:
I came here with five of my friends to celebrate my birthday, and it was perfect!  Everything I imagined it to be.  The place is decked out in girly-ness.  It's weird when you see a man inside because there are so few.  It's a lot smaller and cozier than I thought it would be, but if you are with your best friends then it allows for a more intimate tea party!  

We opted against ordering a tea sets since there were so many of us, and just ordered a bottomless pot of Earl Grey ($8) with each additional person being $1 more.  Then we ordered a lot of food a la carte.  There is a 9.95 minimum per person so we were forced to order more food than we could actually finish, believe it or not.  We came here starving and left incredibly sated.

The scones are amazing.  Warm and soft, combined with the clotted cream and strawberry jam... mmm... Surprisingly easy to break up into pieces so you shouldn't eat an entire one by yourself or you'll have no room for other food.  I was really heartbroken to see jars and jars of Smuckers jam in their storage pantry while waiting in line for the bathroom.  

The crumpets are so-so, save for the lemon curd.  

Ordered a large plate of sandwiches, which allowed us to get 3 sandwiches, quartered.  We ordered 1. bay shrimp and mayo, 2. salmon mousse, 3. pear and stilton.  I only tried the last two, but they were both yummy.  The pear and stilton was very unique, as was the salmon mousse.  Sandwiches are served on a bed of greens, cool.  Also came with coleslaw which was surprisingly good.

We got a chicken curry pasti (pronounced the A as in PASTA not PASTE) which was AMAZING!  Didn't even need the dipping sauce.  The shell was flaky and hot, the inside was flavorful and fragrant.  So great.  

To get to our 9.95 minimum we ordered the Beef Pasti which was definitely not as good as the chicken one.  

We also got an order of the sausage rolls, which are ridiculously hard to cut in halves.  Interesting taste, but would not recommend it.  

Since it was my birthday I got a petite four that was banana-flavored.  It was really cute and thoughtful but less tasty.  They come around with a platter of petite fours for $2.50 each.  We thought they were just giving us all petite fours for free -_- 

All in all, Lovejoy's was everything I wanted it to be.  I had been wanting to come for years and am extremely satisfied with my experience there!
author: Lydia W.

description:
Lovejoy's is usually booked the week between Xmas and New Year's. This year is no different. Hoping to score a table, I signed up for the waiting list and was happy when they called me back with an opening.

High Tea for Two was the perfect cozy way to end the year.  Besides two sandwiches and two bottomless pots of tea, you get two big scones, two cookies, greens and coleslaw for $34.95. My friend and I always end up packing the cookies home - it's a lot of food!

The sandwiches are always tasty.  I had the smoked salmon/cream cheese and chicken-apple-walnut while my friend ordered the cucumber/cream cheese and one other I can't remember.  

Service was exceptional.  Our pots of tea were constantly kept full and hot.   Our gabbing easily had us occupying the table for 2 hours.  When the next reservation was due to arrive, the wait staff gently let us know they needed the table.

The ambiance is cozy and warm, but not stuffy.  I love the little sayings posted throughout the shop. This has become my go-to place for tea with friends. We've tried other tea houses, but they just doesn't compare to Lovejoy's. So, now, if Lovejoy's is closed, we usually just end up waiting until they're open again rather than go elsewhere.
author: M G.

description:
Revisited this place for a bridal shower for 14 people:

love the stilton and pear
love the scone
love the chutney and cheese

I didn't care for the other sandwiches.  

I wish the table seating arrangements were more intimate but it's a hodge podge of a couch, two person table, and a long table for our party. 

2 hour max limit for seatings and they are ALWAYS busy.
author: Jboogie L.

description:
Queen for a Day, what more do you need?

The planets aligned and five of us had two free hours to catch up on the same day at the same time, so I booked a reservation for tea. From the moment we arrived, we had so much fun! We had two waitresses , the table said, "reserved for queens", they explained the teas like they were wines, and the food was excellent. The scones were round, soft, and warm, the real deal. The double Devonshire cream was excellent, the lemon curd fresh, and the strawberry jam not too sweet. My Queen's tea came with all of the above, my own pot of tea, four sandwiches (I had roast beef and chicken salad, yum) and a salad and coleslaw and cookies and a petit four and crumpets. There was plenty of food, we boxed up some to go! Then we strolled around the neighborhood to walk off some crumpet. It was a lovely time and I highly recommend it.
author: Alissa S.

description: Great place to take a date...discuss issues of the day over tea. Chocolate truffle tea is pretty awsome. Don't forget reservations.
author: Dan P.

description: Went here with my mom and sister on a Friday. It was a little busy, but we made a reso, so there were no probs getting a table. We all got the Queen's Tea. Salmon&cream cheese, apple&cream cheese, apple walnut chix salad, prosciutto&gouda cheese - sandwiches were great! The scones were AMAZING. It also came with crumpets, fruit, salad, coleslaw, a petit four, and tea. Really a good deal, and fun experience.
author: Zoe S.

description:
This place has the best scones I have ever had. Hot fluffy raisin scones covered in strawberry preserves, devonshire cream, and lemon curd. O-M-G is probably the only way to put it. I finished mine before my teamates had gotten through half of theirs.

And the crumpets - yum! 

I love the selection of teas, and the bottomless pots.

I wasn't as happy with the sandwiches (I had the apple/cream cheese, and the special of the day which was curry chicken) but I think in general I'm not a fan of sandwiches with a lot of creamy anything so that's probably my fault.

The Queen's tea is the way to go if you want the ultimate experience but it's really a lot of food and you probably won't be able to finish!
author: Katherine P.

description:
Wow, totally did not expect to like this place.  My girlfriend kept wanting to drag me here, and my initial reaction was "Really?  Tea?  Really??"  Eventually I caved, because I'm totally whipped.

Well, I'm glad I did.  Holy hell this place is delicious.  Not only did we go that one time, we've been back a bunch of times, and have even been inspired to try other tea places in the city.  However, none of the other places we've tried are as good as Lovejoy's.

I recommend the "High Tea" if you're in a big group or the "High Tea For Two" if you're going with one other person.  (The "For Two" version is basically two high teas packaged together at a slight discount).  The High Tea comes with (in order of best to worst):
1: Bottomless pot of one type of tea.
2: Warm scone.
3: Two sandwiches.
4: Sugar cookie.
5: Salad.
6: Cole slaw.

Double that for the High Tea For Two, meaning you get four sandwiches total.  There are a lot of variety of teas, from standard stuff like English Breakfast to more unique teas like Passion Fruit.  (I stick with the green teas myself).  The scone is delicious, especially once you spread the accompanying cream and jelly on it.  There are some great sandwich options, too.  My favorites are apple and cream cheese, shrimp and mayo, mandarin orange and cream cheese, and egg salad.

The place is slightly pricey, but you'll come out so incredibly full of good food that it's totally worth it as an "every one in a while" place.  One other thing: definitely get reservations ahead of time, especially if you have more than two people, or else it's going to be a hell of a wait.
author: Chad H.

description:
I really really loved it here. 

Tea parties seem so fancy-smancy but Lovejoy's so quaint and unassuming that it balances the uppiddy feeling of brunch tea time and you can't help but fall in love with it's quirkiness. (Okay, so that kinda sounded like a critic on the back of a novel....)

We ordered high tea for four, since there were the four of us. We got to choose four different teas, all of them bottomless. We chose the strawberry (so good, it really tasted like strawberries, the sweetness of it and the bitterness from the tea, such a good blend), the vanilla black tea (the special of the day, creamy rich vanilla taste), the china rose petals (our favorite, so light and refreshing, all flavors just blended in perfectly; the aroma of the rose hits your nose immediately and the hot tea somehow cools you down, so so so good), and last the blood orange tea (it was good, but a little too citrus-y for me...). We each got to order two sandwiches, a scone, a cookie, salad, and cole slaw. I got the chicken apple and walnut salad sandwich and the horse-radish and roast beef sandwich. Both of them were so yummy! The scone was warm and really delicious. Before every bite I would spread the jam and the double devon cream onto it, and it literally melted inside your mouth. I'm drooling as I am typing. The salad, the cole slaw, and the cookies were rarely touched, so I can't really comment on that.

Service was awesome. We got a cute waitress, who was so helpful with suggestions. And though we didn't make reservations, they gave us a table, but reminded us that someone had reserved the table in an hour, but they never rushed us (but in our own conscience we felt bad and tried to be quickish, but trust me time flies when your with your bffs chatting).

We have already discussed it, and we're definitely coming back again! But with reservations this time, so we can take a while longer here, take more pictures, &talk more. 5 stars!
author: Betty C.

description: It is okay.  It was a turn down since the china was chipped and they don't match - even from tea cup to saucer.  the tea pot had a different lid since the other one was broken.  the food is good, just the roast beef sandwich was dry.  the egg sandwich and the shrimp is good.  the jam and butter are the best with the scones.  the other turn down is that you only get one petite four at the end all this for $30 per person.  I'm sorry but tea and sandwiches are just not worth that price
author: Kay T.

description:
Aromatic teas, buttery crumpets, and delicious scones... if that isn't enough to tempt you then perhaps the warm atmosphere and friendly service will be.  This is one of the BEST places to have teas in the city, and it's pretty obvious.  In my experience you must have a reservation.  Otherwise please expect a long wait.  

There's no parking in the area unless you have a smart car or are willing to circle a 4 mile radius for hours.  However, I must say it's worth it.  I have other favorites, but I will coming back to this Noe Valley gem.
author: Anna K.

description:
Being Chinese,  "drinking tea" means hot food, hot tea, and cheap prices to me, or at least in my backwoods dialect of Chinese. So Lovejoy's tea was a different experience for me: major sticker shock. Popular place.   There was a large crowd waiting at 10:30, despite the fact Lovejoy's opens at 11a. The six of us had reservations at 11am on Saturday.

I shared a High Tea for two with A. We got English breakfast tea and the following sandwiches:

Chicken-Apple Walnut Salad
Artichoke Hummus
Smoked Salmon and Cream Cheese-A's Jewish, so of course he picked it 
Chutney and Cheese-stupid pick on my part bc someone raved about it here. If you don't know what chutney is (like I said, I was stupid), don't get it. 

Tea, sandwiches, shortbread cookies, and salad were all ok, nothing spectacular. It didn't feel very filling either.  I thought it highly overpriced for some tea and crust-less sandwiches. However, my god, the scones with double Devon cream were divine! I was slathering the cream on my scone like a Chinese mom outdoors with sunblock. Every time I walk by now, I yearn for those scones.

Decor: eclectic collection of ornate seats, tables, chairs. Mismatched charm. I loved the different tea sets, cups, creamers etc. Service: great. Everyone was seated quickly. Your pot is refilled quickly no matter how little you've poured out.

As I'm breaking down the price in my head right now, I guess it's not that bad for everything you get. The food is mostly mediocre for what you pay, but the service, decor and ambiance makes for a nice one time experience.
author: Yan E.

description:
Can you say HIGH TEA? On a lovely sunny day, I went with my home girl to this tiny tea room.  The set up is so cramped that I barely had any room to get into my seat.  Let alone the servers go by.  We had the tea for two, which came in your choice of two pots of tea (try the passion fruit tea) so flavorful and refreshing, two scones, two different sandwiches for each person, and a cookie each.  The food was just okay.  Although their finger sandwiches are not bad and have a big selection to what meats you want in it.  Unfortunately, I was too stuffed to try their desserts, they look quite delicious! The price was about $24-28 each person with tax & tips.  I can not recall the exact amount but it was a bit pricey for high tea that did not have tea treats that stood out.  However, for the experience it was not bad.  I wished they had more than one bathroom for its customers, the wait can be pretty long if there's a line.  

P.S. parking is a F*king b*itch here... =/
author: Ann L.

description:
I love this place!  I have been many times, and the food, tea, & service are always excellent.  It's so fun to go with a group of girlfriends, and sit & chat & nibble for hours.  The sandwiches are very good, and pretty much everything I have had on their menu.  

It gets quite crowded on weekends & some afternoons, so definitely make a reservation.
author: Kat W.

description:
Ok. Maybe it's because I'm not girly, but I really don't understand the appeal of tea houses. I feel like I could grab a ton of my grandma's old stuff, throw it in a room and paint it pink and then ta-da! - I'd end up with Lovejoy's decor.

The food here is cute - finger sandwiches piled high on a silver platter along with some scones and salad. They were tasty, but nothing that I couldn't make myself.

I did enjoy their tea selection, though - try the rose!
author: Genevieve W.

description: Had a WONDERFUL time for the Mother's Day Afternoon Tea. It has a shabby chic feel, (no stuffiness here) and even the 3 men in our party didn't feel out of place. It was $35 per person and included limitless pots of our choices of teas, scones, crumpets, sandwiches, salad, cole slaw, and petit fours! Also a small gift for each of us. A very special day!
author: Jocelyn B.

description: Great food and service! They have great teas for all ages. My children loved the kids one.
author: Chris T.

description:
This review is somewhat late in coming, but it's one of the few places that I can remember months after visiting.

We were up in the Bay Area on a roadtrip and Lovejoy's came highly recommended by J's S.F. friend. Now, food-wise I'm as manly as they come, but even I can't say 'no' to a tower of food along with an accompanying pinch of civilization.

Being from L.A., I know about the horrible, nearly nonexistent street parking of S.F. and this place didn't disappoint. However, persistence paid off and I found a space across from their storefront.

Located in Noe Valley, along MUNI's J Line on Church Street (alas, there's no station nearby) Lovejoy's fits right in; quaint, old-world charm with a healthy dose of Victorian kitzch. It's sort of like being transported back in time; a doily-friendly lunching space with curtains, lamps, and other knick-knacks compelling you to sit down on a couch or table and have a cup of tea. 

And a scone. 

With clotted cream.

And some finger sandwiches. 

Or two...

And a petit four. 

And... and...

We opted for sharing a Queen's Tea, the name of which felt like a challenge to my masculinity, but I gotta say that both of us were stuffed afterwards. One highlight of the visit were the freshly made crumpets. I always wondered what exactly crumpets were, but they arrived hot and buttery and reminded me of a really yummy un-split english muffin.

This place also features some lunch items on the menu so if tea's not exactly your thing, you're okay. Our friend mentioned a shepherd's pie, which thankfully, we didn't order.  

The thing I like about afternoon tea is the sense of civilization it imparts to the senses, similar to a kaiseki meal or a cocktail hour with aperitifs, clinking ice, and tony cocktail glasses. I might also mention that the prices are also on the civilized side. I've never found afternoon tea to be a bargain outing and Lovejoy's is no exception, yet I've never come across a place as charmingly quaint as Lovejoy's. 

It's most definitely a place to relax and take your time; savoring the experience in a cozy atmosphere. It's an experience I'd definitely recommend.

Hell, even I caught myself sticking out my pinky finger once or twice.
author: Ken W.

description:
I came here hoping for a great experience, and for the most part, it wasn't a horrible experience until I got up to go to the bathroom, but more on that later.

My friend from Korea was visiting, so I thought this place would be a cute little place to catch up and snack after her flight landed. I made a reservation, and as soon as she landed, we took the J-church down here without incident, and the place was pretty easy to find.

They reserved us a seat on the couch, which was a cute place to sit (albeit a little bad for sitting up straight to eat), so that was nice of them. The menu is a little overwhelming with a bajillion choices, but I ended up ordering the Savory Tea, which included bottomless tea (I picked Vanilla Rooibos) and two sandwiches (I picked shrimp and mayo and smoked turkey and dijon mustard). My friend got the Cream Tea with Apricot Tea. 

Don't get me wrong, the sandwiches were tasty. I just didn't get very many of them, which, admittedly, is the point of tea. I should have gotten the Cream Tea, because my friend's scones were pretty filling and tasty, and I actually ended up wanting fruit after having my tea. So it was a case of ordering the wrong thing, which isn't necessarily something I would penalize Lovejoy's for. 

After getting pretty full off tea, I needed a bathroom break. So I walked into the back, and caught a glimpse of the kitchen where I saw a loaf of bread sitting on the counter. And that was when everything was shattered. It wasn't like, nice white bread. It was Safeway white bread. The kind you can pick up at any Safeway for about $2 a loaf. And then when I thought about it, it wasn't worth it. The sandwiches were good, but they weren't $15 for 8 small triangles good (including unlimited tea). I could have gone to Safeway and made my own delicious shrimp/mayo, turkey/mustard sandwiches. And the ambiance was good, but I couldn't shake the feeling of being made very well aware that I was out of place, that I didn't belong here. The servers were nice enough, but I felt like unless you were pretty acquainted with ordering tea, you would feel kind of uncomfortable ordering and asking questions.

And after that, nothing was the same. It's like that loaf of Safeway white bread broke the illusion, and I was able to see this place for what it was. And I wasn't that impressed, and will probably never come back unless I have a friend who is REALLY into tea. Otherwise, it's just too far and too awkward for me to venture out here.
author: Angeline P.

description: A great expierience. Three of us went for the the first time and our expectatins were met.  a charming place to meet with friends for great tea and food.  their homemade scones are to die for.  I had to take some home.  all the tea sandwiches tasted fresh and were marvulous.  Reservations needed as it is a small place, but oh so charming. After cross the street on Church and visit their shop.  I was amazed and the variety of selection for teas and tea sandwiches.
author: Ann H.

description:
Straight out of a six-year-old girl's tea party fantasy. Lovejoy's is like having tea with your kooky Great Aunt Beatrice. Mismatched floral cups and pots, three-tiered serving trays, and lace. Lots of lace. I went with my mom and sister for my sister's twentieth birthday. We walked in, passed a group of six-year-old girls celebrating a birthday, and got to our seats. The only men in the joint were beaming fathers of six-year-olds, grandfathers, and defeated looking boyfriends and brothers. There was a lot of estrogen.

Our waitress was very sweet, gave suggestions, described teas. We settled on "high tea," all the tea you can drink for $17 per person, plus two sandwiches, a scone, a cookie, some salad and a bit of cole slaw per person. I did not want to like this place. But when the tea arrived, it was perfect. The Irish Breakfast was strong and piping hot, deep and refreshing. The green was herbaceous and nourishing, and the apricot tea was...apricotty?

The scones were bliss-inducing, wonderfully warm pillows of fluff. Not the flaky bricks one usually encounters, these were described as "Irish style," if that means anything to you. The sandwiches were wonderfully fancy versions of the dainty crustless numbers moms make for their daughters. Pear and stilton, salmon and capers, chicken salad, shrimp. Delicate, airy little tastes.

But what really makes this place fun is the service. Tables are labeled "reserved for royalty" or "reserved for the queen," and the waitresses treat you as such, really doing their best to make your experience enjoyable.

I think I may come back for the impressive selection of pub food on the menu!

Oh, and it is easily walkable from 24th st BART!
author: Michael W.

description:
For 20 years I have wanted to go to Lovejoys.  Have had tea at the Palace, the Ritz and two places in the Avenues.  All were fun but this was the best.  The staff are really nice.  I loved the sandwich selection and the scones were yummy -- especially the toppings.  Unlike any other tea, they also gave you both a homemade coleslaw and some salad with dressing.  

The staff was sooooooooo wonderful.  I came with another man and the staff called us cute!!! Not bad for someone way over 50.  But then we were the only men in the room.

With mismatched cups and saucers and odd chairs, it was just a perfect visit.
My partner's opening words were -- "I am happy.  My life is good."

It took almost 20 years
to get to 
love
joy 
with 
love
joy.
author: Skip Y.

description:
AAAAAH!  This place is too cute!

Bring anyone with ovaries here, no matter what age!  What a thrill to have so many of my interests all in one place.  Antiques.  Sammiches.  Tea.  Kitsch.  Sofas for chairs.  Butta!

We got the section with the sofas and it felt like we were at g-ma's living room.  Nothing matches here, which makes you really look at every single mismatched piece.  Wow, this pink is different than this pink you soon discover.  From fine porcelain classic tea kettles to a Cow kettle... something for everyone.

Sandwiches were pretty fun to try out.  If your group is big enough, you can sample perhaps 8 different kinds!  All you need is a nibble!  Scones... wow... I hate scones.  Dry dusty crumbly cotton mouth-inducing pastries.  No!  Not here!  Fresh and moist like a biscuit... and all served with the most exquisites of jams and Double Devon Cream.  I have nooo clue what the heck that is, but it sounds fancy and fancy was delcious!

The Darjeeling was darling.  The Earl Grey was too bitter.  The Dragon Well was swell.  And the Yorkshire Gold was solid!

The waitress was so kind.  She was like someone's dearest mom making sure we had a good time.  With a full room, she kept her cool all day.  Making sure everyone had constant refills.   Going to come back for sure!
author: Chris T.

description:
Love this place. I went on a Saturday; the place seems really full. 

We just had our table for an hour. 

Everyone is so nice there. The food and tea are extremely good. 

Recommend the Cucumber & cream cheese sandwich. Will definitely go again. Nice place for girls day out.
author: Miko H.

description: Cute, comfortable, oddly picturesque, old English theme, extremely friendly and the best scones with clotted cream and jam in the city! I love coming to this place!
author: Hin M.

description:
Honestly, I wanted to give Lovejoy's Tea Room a higher score.  I mean, it's a British tea place.  You don't find this sort of place in the Bay Area. (Yes, you see plenty of milk tea and Thai tea places, but not British tea places.) It's that the place has a good amount of glaring flaws.  It has 3 stars, but the place is really A-OK indeed.  Side note: one of my sisters brought my siblings and I over to this place for her birthday, my only visit to this place.

As I mentioned in the last paragraph, this is a British tea place.  Obviously, the place has the British look when you go inside.  Oh and of course, this is definitely a place ladies generally should feel at ease.

What was good about the place?  I like the surroundings.  The server we had was wonderful.  The staff members as a whole were wonderful I should say.  Of course, the tea would be good. (This is a tea place after all.) You are given your milk and sugar.  Oh and it is awesome that they carry jade tea, but even if your not much of a tea person, there are other drinks to choose from like coffee and hot chocolate. (Side note: for tea and coffee, I need milk and sugar, but I never put either in jade tea.)

Now, I bring out the flaws.  The place is pricey, but it's San Francisco, and adding on, I'll mention a more horrid flaw regarding money in a bit.  I know that this a tea place, but the food was lackluster.  Outside of the scones, a good amount of the food was mediocre at best.  The place is so small, I wonder how someone like Mr. Corey Maggette would manage to feel comfortable without a chair.  Parking is such a bother, but again, it's San Francisco.  I better mention now that the more horrid flaw regarding money (which I checked out just recently) is that each person must spend a little under $10 meaning that for example, if you're just by yourself, you can't just get a crumpet and milk and be good to go because you just spent $7.37 only before the tip.  Even if you add the tip, you're still under the minimum, as that's only $8.48.

I need to get a couple of notes out of the way.  Obviously, if you plan on coming here, make a reservation ahead of time.  Also, you can purchase the cups and other items.  Just go to the store across the street.

I love the atmosphere.  I love the service we received.  I don't love the lackluster food and the money issues.  Lovejoy's is a place I don't mind going to again for tea with crumpets and biscuits.  I just hope the flaws I mentioned are fixed up.

+:  The service is terrific and Lovejoy's Tea Room gets originality points for being a British tea place, a type of place you will not see often in the Bay Area or probably out west for that matter.

-:  The food is seriously lackluster overall and you figure that you get a little more out of each dollar spent.
author: Don U.

description:
When I'm 60, I want my birthday brunch here, with cute old ladies in fun hats! And a sign on the reserved table that says "reserved for Queens"!! And eating tasty little cheese sandwiches and warm scones. And the little marzipan covered cakes that they tempt you with afterward..

Love and Joy!
author: Kaushal P.

description: i shared a querns tea with houseblend tea with my mom.  very interesting food especially like the tea, crumpet and scones with devon cream.  the petite four are cute but too sweet even for me.  ill bring my aunts here next time and plan to try thei lemon curd, salmon sandwich, etc :). ohh and weedays are good!  no need to wait and no crowd!
author: Elc C.

description:
Ever since trying it for the first time in Victoria years ago, we've been hooked.  During a conversation at a party, friends asked if we've tried Lovejoy's - where?  Boy, are we thankful for the tips!

This is what tea should be - cozy, comfortable and non-pretentious like some other places.  We sat at the corner and settled into the comfy settee.  We like all the standard fare, no flavored tea for us - just the good old English Breakfast w/ sugar and milk.  The tea cozy is homey but it sure helps the keep the tea hot/warm!  Can't even describe the quaintness of this place and how charming it is...  We loved looking around and just about everything is for sale here!

We really enjoyed the tea sandwiches.  The bread was very soft and not "squished" from when they cut off the crumb.  High Tea for Two allowed us choice of 4 sandwiches and we enjoyed each one:

Cucumber & Cream Cheese - refreshing and light
Roast Beef & Horseradish - to satisfy hubby's neat for meat and the horseradish has a nice kick to it
Smoked Salmon & Cream Cheese Chutney & Cheese - flavorful
Ham & English Mustard - tasty

This is more enjoyable than Ritz, even the tea and sandwiches were better.  There's no harp playing and large fireplace BUT this is the perfect place to enjoy tea with your special someone, girlfriends, mom...etc.
author: Gloria H.

description:
This quaint and charming Tea room is very Victorianesque. Everything -- from the furniture to the ensembles of the waitresses, is Victorian. The place has an old feel to it. It's extremely girly, so I wouldn't recommend bringing the boys here. Make a reservation for the girls. This would be an awesome "girls day out" place to visit.

I will admit, at first glance, I didn't believe anything on the menu would fill me up. However, each item was so rich with fresh flavor and I was actually stuffed by our meal's end. A downfall -- the prices. I didn't expect tea and sandwiches to be that expensive. The way I see it is, I paid for the experience of trying something new in a great environment, where they definitely pay attention to detail and where high attentive and personable.

If it's just you and another person, order the High Tea for Two. You get to choose several different sandwiches, spring greens, scones, shortbread, biscuits, crumpets, and spreads. I loved the cucumber and cream cheese and apple walnut salad. I literally moaned when I put the crumpet topped with Devonshire cream in my mouth. It just melted...I loved that combination so much, that I went to their retail store across the street to purchase a jar. As far as teas, they offer a wide selection...I would try one from each category.

In short, try it on a Saturday or Sunday morning with girlfriends!
author: Kat M.

description:
My new favorite tea place in SF.

The scone and double devon cream with jam is amazing. and the Black Currant tea is amazing too. :)
author: Xavier G.

description:
My sweets took me there for a birthday tea. They had the table ready for us early and the food was wonderful. The servers took our picture-a few times just to make sure that they had a good shot, and went out of their way to make us feel welcome.
The treat was just that, a treat. It is not food that I can justify spending WW points on, on a regular basis, but for a birthday tea, it was fantastic! Plenty of vegetarian sandwiches and my love-who could ask for anything more? I certainly couldn't.
author: Abi W.

description:
I went here for my birthday with a friend who was visiting from New York. We both loved the place. Despite Lovejoys being in the heart of the bustling noisy city the atmosphere is peaceful and inviting. I asked for a tea that wasn't on the menu and they had it. The staff was very hospitable. The food was delicious. I'm going to have to have green apple and cream cheese sandwiches with my tea all the time now!

I'm glad I found a new place to have tea with my girlfriends since my favorite tea place recently closed.
author: Stasha P.

description:
This place is just delightful! From the owner to the food and ambiance. There is something very endearing about this place that has a million little knickknacks, but somehow they make me feel oh so happy. It's like playing tea with the girls... only that now we are allowed to handle hot liqids! 

 I have an odd food allergy and the owner (Muna) was very attentive and sat down on my couch that was reserved for Queens! :) She listed every ingredient and let me know what I could have. She also sold my friends and I into these wonderful sandwiches that we would have never have tried, but she is so knowledgeable and she was able to let us know that due to our like of other similar cheeses, we would be happy with this choice. 

The tea selections are the best. You can try Green teas, Herbal Teas, you name it. And they can even suggest what would go best with your food selection. It is like having fine wine! 

And then there are the scones... I LOVE THE SCONES. They do sell them separately if you must take some with you or want extras with your order.
