I appreciate the quirkiness of the space staying true to its antique shop past, the 'Reserved for the Queen' sign that secured our table and the aromatic tea selections that can be enjoyed without having to mask the taste with sugar and cream. My advice, get the High Tea (you're going to want the two sandwiches for sure) and split an order of crumpets with your favorite ladies. Don't forget to ask for extra Devon cream.
author: Jane K.

description: I have been going to this tea house since 2002 when one of my friends I met on a trip to France introduced me to this quaint and cute tea house.  I love the ambiance and atmosphere of eclectic antique decor and furniture.  The owners Jillian & Moona are very hospitable and their servers are very friendly, too!  I have always loved their variety of teas and I always order their shepherd's pie and have also tasted & sampled all their variety of sandwiches, salads, scones & biscuits.  I love their presentation of different teapots & cups & saucers and a feeling of taking care of one's self with a cup of tea.  It's just a great place to relax, chill and to have some tea.  Also, it is a great place for showers and b-day parties.  I have been to a few there for ladies'  day outing and with my late BF/fiance - he was addicted to their shepherd's pie, too.  I can't wait to bring my granddaughter here, too when she can sit down and appreciate it (she's still only 2 years old).  You need to make reservations here in advance.  It can get real full and crowded because of its popularity.  I highly recommend this place to visitors and locals!
author: Arlene Z.

description: This place is just darling- very cute and comfortable but be sure to make reservations. I've got the say though....finding parking on a sunny Saturday afternoon is pretty difficult so be sure to give yourself more time. It's a great place for a date with your lover or your girlfriends. My husband and I shared a High tea for one (we had the smoked salmon and cream cheese and chicken walnut apple sandwich) and ordered an additional salad and it was just right. I just adored the tea cups so we went across the street afterwards and bought 4 sets for myself and 2 sets for my mother in law.
author: Taiga M.

description: A fabulous brit feast. The food is excellent and the decor is just hokey enough to be fun. Their scones are the best I've ever had - not these dry, sandy triangles with miserly flecks of dried fruit which you find in most bakeries.  These are light, moist biscuity things with juicy raisins and currants tucked inside. Their sandwiches (crust free, of course) are also great. For me the only misstep are the crumpets-which come straight from Safeway. If whomever bakes their scones would make the crumpets as well, I'd move in.
author: Jordan J.

description: I had the best time at this tea room. I could spend hours there, and I did because they kept refilling my little tea pot. I loved nibbling on the finger foods we ordered that were carefully displayed on a tiered tray. It was such fun. I think all you need to come here is a good pal and a reservation and Lovejoy's will do the rest. An absolute must do for anyone who enjoys a spot of tea!
author: Miss B.

description:
I like tea, tea likes me, makes me want to go pee-pee!

So anyways, this place was really really good!  Service was great and the tea and sammiches were fantastic.  Only gripe?  It was a little too crowded for my taste.  I knew it being a tea house it would be cluttered with afternoon tea goods, but I felt really squished in there as opposed to other tea houses I have been to.  All in all, I recommend any afternoon tea lover to try this place out!
author: Keika L.

description:
I really didn't want to come here, what with doilies, china, and chintz everywhere, but friends dragged me there kicking and screaming.   I mean, who the heck cares about tea, crumpets, and cucumber sandwiches (on "wonderbread") with crusts cut off?  FROU FROU. 

I have to admit, I did enjoy the surprisingly tasty edibles.  The tea was okay and most of the food was really good.   I ended up having a good time there with friends Polly Prissypants and Clyde Frog.  Yay.
author: Animal K.

description:
This is a really fun place to have tea. It's often estrogen heavy (filled with women in flowery clothing with a couple sheepish looking guys thrown in), but if you can get over the girly decor, it's great. Teas are good, service is very friendly and quick, and they have delicious tea sandwiches, particularly tasty scones, and petit-fours for dessert.

We always get cream tea for two (scones and fruit, with a bottomless pot of your choice of tea), with a side of tea sandwiches. I particularly like the stilton and pear sandwiches, but most of them are great. All the black teas we've had there were pretty good, and the atmosphere is fun.

It's super crowded all the time, I recommend making reservations, especially on weekends. We're lucky enough to live nearby so we just walk in and if there's a long wait, we go somewhere else.
author: Andrew H.

description:
This place is right down the street for me and that's why I'm being so generous with the stars.  It's a decent place to go with your girlfriends for tea HOWEVER...  The mismatch tea settings are cute unless you get the wrong one teapot.  Mine was so heavy that I couldn't pour the tea without getting burned!  I like antiques and all but sometimes you got to draw the line.  The furniture is so old and rickety.  We sat on this dusty old couch that was too high for the coffee table.

Aside for the decor, the price is a little bit high compared to Lisa's Tea Treasures in Menlo Park (you even get free dessert at Lisa's!).  But if you live in the city, it's worth a try to go with friends.
author: Marobin L.

description:
I threw a baby shower here for a girlfriend who really enjoys high tea.
Although a little too loud for a traditional baby shower, Lovejoy's was a great experience. 
It is indeed a bit cluttered and a little grandmotherly in it's decor but that's the part of the charm.  I really liked the hominess of the place, it brought comfort to me on that cold rainy day.  The tea was lovely, our table had Earl Grey and  Blood Orange teas. We ordered an assortment of sandwiches which were all yummy. There was actually quite a bit of food and we ended up taking some home. I loved the tea scones, served warm and with lemon curd and devon cream. My favorite sandwiches were roast beef and horse radish, egg and onion, and the hummus. 
The staff is very accommodating and gracious.   We had a tea leaf reader which added to the fun of the afternoon. 
We thoroughly enjoyed ourselves and would definitely be back.
author: Nou S.

description:
I took a couple sweet little girls I know out for tea the other day. I gave them a bunch of choices - the Ritz, the Palace, King George hotel, and Lovejoy's. They picked this place because it's closest to my house and they wanted to bake cookies and have tea.

I'd been here once before for an intimate baby shower on a weekend. It was swamped. We waited although we had reservations and were encouraged to leave swiftly so the hoards of other ladies could take our table.

But my recent visit was during the week in the afternoon, so we strolled in without a reservation and enjoyed a leisurely tea. Just as it should be.

My tiny guests were delighted with the holiday decor, the careful attention to personalize our service (the girls were served their hot chocolate in an adorable "Alice in Wonderland" teapot and no request for more whipped cream was declined), and our choice spot on the curvy red sofa.

The tea selection is fabulous, and the servers are wonderful.
author: Vanessa L.

description:
SO CUTE.
this is the best place in the city to go with some girlfriends on a lazy afternoon when you have TONS to gossip about. 
its pure delightful girl-time. the tables and settings are all mismatched and adorable and the homebaked goods that come on the trays are DELICIOUS.
queens tea is by the best and it comes with assortments of tiny sandwiched, fruit, salad, crumpets, cakes, etc. HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!
author: EM F.

description:
i've been wanting to try love joys ever since i've tried secret garden 2 years ago. my friends all rave how much better it is so finally me and the hubby went to try it this year

he's been trying to get reservations for over a week and finally on saturday they told him to just walk in and hopefully they can get us a spot. i can see why when i came in it was completely packed. so many gals with their baby showers and bdays going on. i guess since it was super busy everything was a lil lacking

i honestly didnt enjoy it as much as i thought i would like at secret garden. i had the mango black tea and he had forest berries. both teas were yummy and the sandwishes weren't as delicious as i have imagined. the scones were great!

we choose the high tea for 2. it seemed like a steal. we had 4 diff sandwichs, cucumber and cream cheese, love joy special (so far my fav there, its tuna, celery, and i think apples) chicken and walnuts,  and man we had one more sandwich but i dont remember. it came with a salad and a cole slaw. we both didnt eat the cole slaw. the sandwiches were good. i think if it wasn't as busy i would have enjoyed everyting much more.
author: KK M.

description: My friend took me here for my birthday.  She is a dentist in Noe Valley.  I had the best time ever.  Great staff, great environment, and fantastic food and teas.  I would go back here any day of the week, and Sunday!  I wish we had a tea room like this in Sausalito!
author: Ashley E.

description:
Even though I've not YET been here, I love the idea of it and the look of it--so yeah, full stars. My husband peered through the window and said "I think I just went through menopause", so I'll very likely be coming here with my girlfriends but I am so looking forward to it. Since we're moving into the neighborhood very soon, it won't be long before I try it. Cant wait!

UPDATE: I went here solo to test it out, and loved it! I cant wait to sit and have tea with pals. Also, I went across the street to LoveJoys attic and bought and awesome candle chandelier.
author: rachael s.

description:
I would come here every week if I could--I love the experience. The venue is so interesting and eclectic. I love the variations in cups, saucers and teapots (although it seems like they always serve Earl Grey in the same British one) not the mention the chairs and tableclothes.

Recommendations: If you have a party of 4 or more, then ordering a hightea for one less than the number of people is a reasonable amount of food for people who are hungry, but not starving. The sandwiches are all really tasty, although I particularly like chicken and asparagus, roastbeef and horseradish, and pear stilton. I also like the sausage rolls with baked beans sidedish. Of course any tearoom wouldn't deserve a good rating unless I loved their clotted cream (I have a bit of scone to go with my clotted cream and strawberry preserves). I usually pass on the optional petit fours.

Reservations are a must on the weekends for large parties. It is a bit crowded as they have a lot of tables in a limited space. I've seen a number of shower parties here, but it might be hard to play games that require space. Also, if you're a guy, then be secure when going. You might be the only one.
author: Cynthia Y.

description:
This place is very not me. Estrogen overload.  Very frilly, very girly, very pink.  My grandmother would love it.  HOWEVER.... the food is pretty great.  

OMG.  Double Devon Cream.  Total mouth orgasm.  I ate some right out of the container.  No shit.   


One star off because it's a bit spendy.
author: Katie E.

description:
Best tea sandwiches in the city, hands down.  I've been to the Ritz, the Palace, etc, and this place takes the proverbial cake. Don't miss the crumpets.  Mmm..crumpets. With jam and Devonshire cream! Your inner anglophile would be so pleased.  

Plus, the staff was kind enough to accomodate a to-go order on a busy Sunday, only gently asking me to order at least a day in advance next time (note taken) without being the least bit bitchy about it.  I left with a platter full of tea sandwiches (covered in moist towelettes to keep them from drying), and even extra thinly sliced cucumbers for garnish. Wow, how nice.  I also usually pick up their tea room blend at the shop across the street. I think you get a discount if you take tea at the shop, and their black teas are extra fine so it takes less time for me to get a good, strong steep. 

If you know someone who'd appreciate some tasty, dainty sammiches but can't deal with the frou setting, a takeaway order would do nicely as it can be enjoyed in a more man-friendly setting. Just remember to order at least a day in advance.
author: Ms. Q.

description: yummyyyy! just went this past saturday~ love the warm scones and it is such a cute dainty place! I went with a good friend and ordered the high tea for two and got to choose two types of tea (pomegranate green tea and a more favorful mango tea) and 4 types of sandwiches. YUMMMM I really really enjoyed the shrimp and mayonnaise sandwich! We also had the smoked salmon with cream cheese, chicken with asparagus (tasted a little like baby food), and.. roast beef with horse relish that I thought was kind of overwhelming. I think I got too full from the scone! hehe over all very comfy seats and perfect place to chat and munch!
author: Alice S.

description:
Came here for a little girls' afternoon out for my birthday. I was afraid we'd be turned away at the door for being late, but actually we were seated but had to wait at least 10 minutes before our server paid any attention to us. Another plus: we actually sat for about 2 hours even though I saw them ask a table of two to leave bc they "had other people waiting." On to the food part:

Of course, everything was cute and dainty and the only thing old lady-ish about the place was the musty/stuffy air that afternoon. Our party was delighted by the High Tea for Two. Scones smothered with cream and preserves were the group's favorite, but we were also pretty satisfied with the sandwiches, especially the fig and olive tapenade. 

Overall, it's a great place to meet up or celebrate a special occasion, although it is a very female dominated atmosphere. Parking wasn't too much of a problem. Like everyone else said, make reservations.
author: Jessica K.

description: Had grreat expectations about this tea room but disappointed to find they use paper napkins and foil-wrapped butter.  Sorry, I can do better than this at home serving tea.
author: May K.

description:
My favorite place in the City!!!

I frequently stop by to have High Tea with friends.  The staff is by far the BEST the City has to offer.  They are always friendly and helpful.

LOVE the selection of teas and sandwiches.

I enjoy stopping in on a Saturday or Sunday afternoon and unwind from the crazy week.  I have been to many other places in the City for tea, but none of them compare to LoveJoy's.

This place has a very homey feel...like going home to visit mom, or grandma.  A great place to go when the weather is chilly outside and you are looking for a nice comfortable place to relax.  There is always some type of party going on whether it be a baby shower, bridal shower, birthday party, or just friends getting together.

I can't say enough about LoveJoy's.  It is my home-away-from-home...my sanctuary.  I always know that I can go to LoveJoy's to relax from my busy/hectic life.

Thank you ladies for making my experiences at LoveJoy's a constant enjoyment in my life.
author: Danny M.

description: Went here for my birthday lunch, a gift to me from my sister.  I saw this place on "Check Bay Area Please" and decided to give it a try.  I was not disappointed. We got the Queen's tea and I was so surprised at the selections.  Bottomless pot of English Breakfast Tea.  I had the stilton and pear and the salmon and cream cheese.  Delish.  The crumpet came a little later and I was pleasantly surprised.  I had never tried one, and I wanted another as soon as I tasted it.  I have never been a fan of scones, but this is also the first time I had a hot scone.  It was wonderful.  Great experience, my first time at a tea house.  I will be back!
author: Alyssa d.

description: We came here to celebrate wedding dress shopping and it was so much fun!!  The place is super cute, our server was awesome, and the tea was free-flowing.  We had a large group and ordered Queen's tea- and it was so much food!  And it was all delicious and not rushed.  It was a great experience- a highlight to our day.
author: Amarissa K.

description: This place is absolutely darling! Love the tea, love the food, love the ambiance. I go here all the time for any sort of girls' occasion, like when my mom visits, or a girlfriend has a birthday, or just to bond with my gal pals. Not that this is exclusively a chick place, I've definitely seen some dudes partaking of the fine offerings. Why not? The devon double cream is UNBELIEVABLE as is the lemon curd. Don't even ask what it is, just spread it all over everything, you won't be disappointed!!
author: Becky P.

description: The reservation was kinda difficult to make, I had to call several times for them to finally reply my call. After my first time there, I thought the food was not bad, and they have quite a bit choices of tea too.... But after I've been to other tea places in sf, omg I realized this place is great!! XDD  The other places I've been to, their bread doesn't taste as good, they didn't have that many types of tea, and they are much more expensive too.  So me and my friends decide that we will definitely go visit lovejoy's again :D
author: michelle l.

description: I had the best time here for my birthday! I made reservations in advance because weekends do tend to fill up quickly. It was not a problem when I did so. The staff were incredible accommodating and helpful. The day of my party, the ladies made sure everything was good to go. It was intimate gathering and super chill. We had a great time laughing and eating and drinking delicious tea. We had the Queen's Tea. I chose the Royal Blend...sooo good. The tiers came with delicious sandwiches, cookies, biscuits, fruit, salad and at the end petite fours. Oh my. So much food. By the end, we were full and happy. I treated my friends to a tea leaf reader...That was an amazing experience, too. Tricia was great...we had a ball! ;) The only thing I would say that I wasn't too fond of (but I understand why they have it) is the time limit. At the end, we did feel a little rushed but I suppose we were having so much fun..time flew! Oh well. I would definitely recommend this place to anyone who loves tea time...! I will definitely come back......LOVE.
author: Mel P.

description: Wonderful is the only way to describe each visit to Lovejoys! As a huge fan of English tea, nothing gets the fix like a pot of Lovejoys blackcurrant. Indulging for a spot of cream tea is something I didn't think I'd get to do again after moving back to the US from England. The scones, crumpets, and clotted cream are always top-notch, the service bright and helpful, and the decor is as cute as it gets. I can't recommend this place enough if you're after an unapologetically girly indulgence.
author: Alissa L.

description: Had a girls' only tea party here for a 30th birthday party and even as grown women, we loved it! We got the Queen's Tea which came with plenty of tea, sandwiches, salad, scones and crumpets to fill us up. The space was super adorable and was a perfect place to catch up with the girls.
author: Stacy L.

description: Tea & Scones are good. Scones are not as good as  you would find in England, but close. Pricey. Worth checking out for special occassions.
author: Duy N.

description:
this was my first time at lovejoy's and I must say I had a great time. They have a great selection of tea and sandwich bits. The people there are very  nice. price is just about right. decor was not overdone.
I highly recommend this place.
author: J W.

description:
We were 5 adults and 2 children for high tea and our 'royal' reservation saw us sat at a couple of sofas. 

The atmosphere of the place was quaint with its mismatched items, the food was tasty, but ......here are the drawbacks:-

 - the tea was VERY weak - we opted for the Tea Room Blend.
 - the 4" plates provided were impractical for eating salad.
 - a thimble full of Devonshire Cream for 3 of us to share .... is impossible, trust me, I'm a full fat whore as are other ladies in my party
 - and lastly, and most importantly, the woman serving us kept putting hot pots of tea right beside my 1 1/2 year old!!!!

In short, too twee of a tea for me.
author: ohreleigh ..

description: Great value, real pleasure in the scones, crumpets, lemon curd! Pleasant altho loud atmosphere. Could use a second bathroom, for sure! Kinda crowded at Christmas - but a great place for Afternoon Tea.  I am looking forward to another visit - good looking pub food on other half of menu!  Will be making this an annual or more visit!  Atmosphere real - not a candy cane, or Alice in Wonderland, like some places turn into. Able to stuff both sexes equally, with satisfaction all around!
author: Christie L.

description: I had my birthday party here sometime in June, and I'm glad I chose LoveJoy's to host my birthday party. We had 11 people and everyone enjoyed their experience, even the guys! They were extremely accommodating, and were really nice and patient to me and my friends even though we were sometimes embarrassingly a little too loud. My party had a little corner of the tea room to ourselves, where they set up a cute little row of sofas and chairs for us to sit at and enjoy our tea. The tea room was decorated shabby chic, and all the tea ware you are served with are mismatched yet adorable; but that adds to the shabby chic vibe!  The teas were phenomenal, I've never had such delicious and fragrant tasting teas in my life! My favorite teas that we sampled that day were the Ginseng tea and Vanilla Rooibos. The food was good, I REALLY recommend everyone order at least one scone for themselves, you might end up ordering more because they are the best things I have ever put in my mouth! They are ridiculously buttery and delicious, I tried to savor my scone as much as I could since it was so good. The sandwiches were pretty good, but not as good as I thought from reading other previous reviews. We ordered the horseradish sandwich with beef (?), I wasn't able to sample it since I don't eat red meat but it was a no go for all of my friends. The curry sandwich was a little overpowering for us. The standouts among the sandwiches were the chicken artichoke & LoveJoy's special. The citrus salad was refreshing and tasty.  What really made my time at LoveJoy's special was at the end of our tea session, the staff came out with a petit four with a little candle on it, which was like a mini personal cake to me! They also gifted me a cute little faux diamond encrusted tiara. Love that extra touch, it really made my birthday at LoveJoy's a special and great experience. I will definitely be back for their scones and tea!
author: The T.

description: A bit overpriced for tea and sandwiches but a lovely experience ;)
author: Tiff W.

description:
My two daughters and I have a tradition of going for tea every year on the first day of school.  It's a tradition I love and hope to continue forever and ever...  Anyway, we used to go downtown to either The Compass Rose (no longer around), one of the other fancy hotels, or to The Rotunda at Neiman-Marcus.  The last few years we've stayed local and gone to Lovejoy's.  The prices are much more affordable than downtown (about half that of Neiman's.)  The food is also fresher and more abundant.  Service is wonderful and accomodating.  The only reason I did not give five stars is that sometimes the seating is cramped/uncomfortable.  Today we were seated three across on a very soft, squishy couch -- kinda impractical to drink tea and eat scones on.  Aside from that, we love Lovejoy's!
p.s.  The tea service for the under-10 crowd is awesome --- a big pot of hot chocolate with whipped cream, a couple of tea sandwiches and a few other goodies.  It's my younger daughter's idea of nirvana.
author: Gina F.

description:
My friends and I came across this place on yelp and decided to try it because it has better reviews than other places like Crown & Crumpet.

Note that their last seating is at 4.30-5pm.

The place was very well decorated. There were antique sofas and mirrors. They had cute little trinkets and even a red telephone booth display! It had a vintage feel to it.
The tea sets and plates were also beautiful, but strangely, they were mismatched. Hmmm
Anyway, it's still a good place for snacks, to hang out and relax.

My friends and I shared the Queen's tea (complete with scones, crumpets, salad, sandwiches and lots more) and I think it was enough for 2 people. We ended up paying $15 each.

I like it that they had a great selection of teas and sandwiches (check out the menu on their website). I tried the peach and china rose tea and for sandwiches, smoked salmon and pear & Stilton.  The teas were very fragrant and the sandwiches were pretty good even though they were so small. I had scones with raisins and strawberry preserves. It was heavenly!

The people who worked there were very welcoming, exceptionally patient and friendly. I really enjoyed the experience and I really recommend Lovejoy's!
author: Roland R.

description: Lovejoy's is really fun for a girlie afternoon with your friends, and I'm already trying to figure out when I can go back.  It's a little cramped inside, but other than that great experience.  The sandwhiches are fresh, and the offerings of tea are widely varied, so you can always find something you like.
author: Nicole Q.

description: I had a lovely afternoon tea at Lovejoy's with another tea loving friend, and it is an afternoon we will always remember.  Lovejoy's is a truly San Francisco experience in a quaint Victorian setting.  I am not sure it could quite be replicated anywhere else.  Even in the summer, the city weather is cool enough to enjoy a lovely afternoon tea.  We loved exploring another part of the city by coming to Noe Valley.  We did not order the pettifores and our tiered tea plate looked small for the price but it turned out to be more than enough and nicely made.  The servers helped us to select teas and sandwiches that we would enjoy and their recommendations were valuable and appreciated.  We took a short drive to see the street art at Balmy and I recommend this as a part of the afternoon city experience.  The owner of Lovejoy's helped us to find our way to our next destination, very accommodating to "tourists."  We did not make a reservation and were asked to give up our table at the end of an hour and a half.  That was enough time for us, but just be prepared that their relaxing tea tables are on a schedule.
author: B P.

description:
i had the best date of my life here so even though that romance is dead (through no fault of my own, you should know), this place will always hold a special spot in my (broken) heart.  aww.  

anyway, they have good vegan options that they will happily point out if asked (the fig tapenade is reallllly good) and i love the adorable mismatched flatware.  they also kindly donated the space and food to a recent rocket dog benefit and for that, i will always have extra special love for them.  a totally unique, fun, san francisco experience.  this is a great place to bring your mom to, she will flip.  vanilla roobis tea is a must try!  this is the most scattered review of all time.  

god, that was a good date.  le sigh.
author: Laura B.

description:
What's with all the hype.  This place has to be one of the best reviewed eateries on yelp.  

I was mislead/invited one Saturday morning to go to a brunch here.  I had no expectations other than that the place would be overpriced and overrated.  Lovejoy's came through with my prediction.

In our co-ed group, we sat, drank tea with an air of pretentiousness and nibbled on ridiculously tiny sandwiches. We gossiped and laughed at each other's anecdotes.  The company was incredible but the place has nothing going for it.  

Perhaps I'll never understand why some people feel it is justified to shell out over $20 for tea (which is just the leaves and water) and tiny sandwiches that are made from wonderbread and a cucumber.  It's really awe-inspiring and criminal that an institution such as Lovejoy's even gets to stay in business for such horrible business practices.    

Why don't people just buy the tea themselves at specialty places and make their own better tasting wonderbread sandwiches.  I don't believe in the ambiance of this place.

Just my 8 cents.
author: Scott L.

description: How can you NOT love Lovejoy's?  This is a quaint eclectic restaurant located at the corner of Church and Clipper.  I brought my mother and mother in law there for a girls day out  The menu is straight forward - choose a sandwich or two and pick a tea of your choice.  There are plenty of food options - we opted for the High Tea.  For $17.99, you choose two sandwiches, one tea - it also comes with a scone (with jam and devon cream - yummo), salad, cole slaw and the best shortbread cookie.  Make reservations - this pace gets crowded fairly quick since it's popular for locals.  The staff is more than friendly which makes the environment perfect for small gatherings.
author: J H.

description: The premier tea spot in SF.  But must it always be described as a spot for the ladies?  I am a (straight) male and I can't get enough of high tea.  Probably because I got hooked while tramping around Scotland.  Seriously, the average American who thinks tea is for old ladies doesn't know what they're missing.
author: Wes M.

description:
Not to be redundant, but I Love Lovejoy's.

Service: Excellent.  First, they try their best to accommodate your party, even though they are booked up the wazoo.  RESERVATIONS, early ones, are a must.  I got lucky and was able to squeeze into a one hour slot, which they ended up being able to extend.  The tea came out immediately and the food followed soon after.  

Food: NOM NOM NOM.  Their sandwiches were delicate and delicious, and quite substantial.  Their scones were not that spectacular (but not bad by any means) and their tea is FABULOUS (China Rose Petal = No. 1!!!, vanilla herbal tea = def not no. 1).  They are really helpful with what is good and/or popular on the menu.  We got the Tea-for-two for $34, plus an additional $17 for a third person.  We left quite full and very pleased.  

Price: Not bad for afternoon tea.  Going to the Ritz, which is usually my favorite, will cost you double.  This is a lot of yummy bang for your buck.  

Location: Easy to get to and easy to park.  What more could you possibly need?!   Their decor is nice too, not overly Victorian-doll-overkill, as many tea rooms tend to be.  Do they really think I like eating with so many dolls watching me?

Highly recommended!  Or maybe not, I don't want their reservation wait lines to get even more ridiculous.
author: Alison K.

description: I live a couple of blocks from Lovejoy's so I see it all the time when I drive by.  My friend and I come here for tea and it's fun and girlie.  We always feel very welcome here, since the staff is so friendly.  They even accommodated my friend's little baby, which isn't easy in that place...lots of breakable stuff.  You can feel the estrogen in the room when you walk in.  It's definitely the spot for a girl get together.  The food is good (sandwiches.)  The sweet food is great (scones.)
author: Kristina R.

description:
FOOD/DRNK:
1.) High tea for 2! = Comes with two pots of tea, choice of 3 or 4 type of sandwiches, two scones, two sugar biscuits, salad, and coleslaw. The food snacks are brought on this stacked tray, displayed nicely. 
2.) Smoked Salmon Cream Cheese Sandwich = Mmmm! I was hella craving smoked salmon the other day, so this totally satisfied
3) Smoked Mouse Sandwich = Hm, it just tastes like mushy smoked salmon spread.. it was good
4.) Hummus = O man this was pretty good
5.) Chicken Apple = This was alright. I'm not sure but I thought I tasted a hint of goat cheese, and I personally don't like goat cheese
6.) Tea = I forget what kind we had, but it was not anything fruity nor vanilla. Just some variety of black tea... But I must say it had a really nice aroma, and it tasted especially good with milk and sugar. Mmm! Basically a pearl milk tea without the pearls! Which lead me to wonder, were the English actually the first to drink milk tea? And not the Hong Kongese!? And why have I not had English tea time before?!!?!! 
7.) Scones = MMMmmmm!!! Oh man!! Fresh scones are pretty darn good! Specially with the ... butter? that they provided... and jam...
8.) Sugar Biscuits = just tasted like a dense sugar cookie :P
9.) Coleslaw = Ehhh how is coleslaw supposed to be like? I'm only used to the one from KFC hahaha. So this coleslaw seemed kinda plain and not much taste
10.) Salad = Um it had tangerines in it? Came with a little thing of Thousand Island I believe..

SERVICE:
We lucked out and got the server with an English accent!

ATMOSPHERE:
Very cute eclectic, mismatched antique furniture, mismatched English tea cups saucers and pots. The atmosphere is casual. Some table seating, and some sofa seating. Very cute for a group of ladies who want to catch up, or DEFINITELY major huge brownie points for a guy to bring a girl here for a first date.
author: Angela L.

description:
ever wonder what it would feel like to live in a victorian dollhouse?

well, wonder no more, for lovejoy's is here, the most adorably quirky teahouse in sf!

my friend's bridal shower was here, so we went all out with the queen's tea.  the tea includes: coleslaw, spring greens, scones, crumpets, cookies, fruit, sandwiches, and various teas (i tried to rooibos, chestnut, and a black over the course of the tea.)

everything was beautifully presented (i love the mismatched china and teaware!), the service was beyond personable and friendly, and everything, above all, tasted great.

so, whether for a bridal shower, an intimate brunch option, or a quiet afternoon for yourself, consider lovejoy's!  it is a true treat!
author: Jill k.

description:
very chintz-y...like victorian living magazine threw up a little, but with a definite element of kitsch.

i heart this place. i like the aprons the ladies wear.

i think i used to order the 'cream tea'. that clotted cream for the scones rocks my world. 

i can't wait to visit sf again so i can go here.
author: Julie T.

description: I have been to lovejoy's several times over the last few years, and it has never let me down. Prompt, friendly service, delicious tea and crumpets, and a cozy atmosphere, all make lovejoy's the destination spot for my friends and I, whenever we are celebrating!!
author: E. v.

description: This place was a let down.  After reading all the reviews on how good the tea experience was at Lovejoy, I was expecting so much more.  I took the family here on Friday morning, and the place was half full.  We ordered the Savory Beef pasty, Shepard's pie, scones, chicken and turkey sandwiches, earl grey tea, hot chocolate.  There was nothing special about any of it.  I can't figure out how this place got such good ratings.  The ambience of the place is old and musty and the food is just so so.  It cost us about $20/person...I was disappointed and felt let down by all the reviews I read about this place.
author: Kevin J.

description: Best tearoom experience in years!! I love that their tea pots are bottomless and the decor is adorable!! Must try!
author: Allison S.

description:
My partner and I took our 7 year old niece to LoveJoy's for a "fancy tea party".  The atmosphere was cute, the teapots were actually beautiful, but the food was god awful.  I did enjoy the pot of the house tea.  My partner had a tisane which was very well done and our niece ended up fully cracked out on a pot of hot chocolate.  The hot chocolate was in an Alice in Wonderland tea pot which was really amazing and kept the interest of the table as we attempted to swallow our food.
OK, the food...
The sandwiches were so budget that I was embarrassed.  The niece wouldn't even eat the very basic jelly and cream cheese (in all honesty she doesn't have very high standards).  It was just kinda all bland, sweet, and nasty too.  Bread was stale.  Uh oh, a bad start.  The grown up's sandwiches were just as bad if not worse.  Chicken salad with asparagus sounds really fab until you realize that the asparagus came from a can. Gross, mushy, stale.  The other sandwiches were not gross but were disappointing and seriously lacked even basic freshness.  
Tea is great, stick with the scones and clotted cream, stay away from the other food.
author: Yo G.

description: Remember tea parties as a child with your stuffed animals surrounding you as you are adorned in your mother's hat and gloves? Well, I don't, but I've always wanted such a childhood memory, and that's exactly what I get when I go to Lovejoy's. I love the mismatched china, the excellent tea, and the proper British tea food. I recommend the egg salad sandwich and the house blend tea. It's a lovely place.
author: Leah F.

description: Very cute and cozy. The scones are so good and I loved the salmon and cream cheese sandwiches. The waitresses are friendly and helpful and they really make sure your teapot doesn't have a chance to get empty. A great place to go with girlfriends for a treat out.
author: Angelyn C.

description: If I feel like doing something British (not involving Elizabeth Hurley, Rachel Stevens, English Muffin of the Month, or a Spice Girl), then Lovejoy's is a great destination for that tea experience. Parking is a right bastard in the area, but if you are in the area there's no other place (unless you make a trip to some hoydee toydee hotel for similar but more expensive fare). Decor and atmosphere are not as intimate as the cottage at The Tea Cozy in Cambria, but the food and tea make up for it.
author: Ken K.

description: This place is definitely 5 stars in the decor department. Full of little trinkets, teapots, cute chandeliers, and ornaments, the interior is like a hoarder's attic, but neater. All worries become a thing of the past once you step into this tea room. Everyone wears a smile, laughing and enjoying tea from quirky teapots. You start to relax every part of your body until you take a glance at the menu...Are you kidding me?! $8 for bottomless tea?! $13.95 for 3 crackers, 2 slices of smoked salmon, a few slices each of tomato and cucumber, and a handful of walnuts...and the fact that someone was timing our stay and ready to kick us out after 2 hours was not what I consider worry-free. I am not in heaven anymore.
author: Melissa Y.

description:
I'm a fancy boy - I love Lovejoys.  Yes this 6 foot tall, 200 lbs, one time varsity athlete (now just a weekend warrior) loves his lemon curd and warm scones.  Mmm...cry havoc and set free the drool!

High tea here is unpretentious and delicious.  More important to the last vestiges of my masculinity, it is filling and plate lickingly delicious.  Ok, so Lovejoys has far more doilies than a man should volunteer to be around, but the Queen's tea is outstanding enough to get me to turn in my man-card for an afternoon of finger sandwiches every time.  

Men this is how it works when you get the Queen's tea (my recommendation).  First, you get an endless pot of tea (which means I drink several pots without realizing it and spend the rest of the day peeing) and choice of a pair of finger sandwich flavors.   I like egg and onion and pear and gorgonzola the best, but I've had almost every flavor and they are great (although the shrimp one is a bit cat-foody).  The sandwiches come cut in little triangles, but you get a bunch of them so it's satisfying and delicious.  This is all served on a three tiered silver platter/tower, in which the top tier is covered in fruits and the second tier is where the real goodness hides.  Tier two has the warm scones (soft, hot and with raisins) on which you have the option of spreading clotted cream (think super-thick whipped cream), lemon curd (FANTASTIC), and/or fresh berry preserves (highly recommended to combine with the clotted cream).  There are also shortbread cookies in case your heart needed more butter and sugar.  The sandwiches are on their three, along with salad greens and some dressing.  

While you scarf up this bounty, over extend your bladder, and whittle away at your manhood, the waitstaff will come by to give you warm crumpets.  Crumpets serve as another vessel for the toppings on tier two.  At this point in your meal when you should be wrestling with, "I'm a man, I had high tea, I'm full, I think like being fancy... this is so confusing," the waitstaff will come out with petit-fours as a knockout blow.  Think bite sized cake.

To survive Lovejoys use my trick to maintaining the illusion of masculinity: take the women in your life here to celebrate their live events / hollidays.  They will love it, you get to eat the goodness and you can tell your buddies you were forced to go because it was your wife's birthday, because your sister had a wedding shower, etc.  Little will they know that you've turned into a fancy boy just like me.  

p.s. If you are going here, always have a reservation.
author: Aaron M.

description:
Ok, so here I am trying to plan a tea party. I originally tried for Lovejoy's but they were all booked that day. Ok, no biggie I figured it would be more fun to do at home anyway. Just imagine how thrilled I was to learn they would do a take out order. So I called. 

The person in charge of catering calls me back leaves a 10 minute message on my voicemail telling me to email her the specifics and she would get back to me. Great, in theory...love email but for things like this I prefer to talk through the ideas with someone on the phone. I find that a 5 minute conversation is much more efficient than 10 emails back and forth especially if the customer is not sure what they want. 

So I call instead. I give her the benefit of the doubt she must have been busy, but then don't take the call. She made it seem like a major imposition to speak with a potentially good customer, I was most likely going to spend quite a bit there.

I was treated so rudely I will NEVER step foot in Lovejoy's again nor will I EVER recommend anyone call them about catering. She was completely rude.
author: eve m.

description: Too cute for words.  Looks exactly like a kid's tea party but with grown ups at the table.
author: Danielle B.

description: I love this place!   The best place to gather with friends and  catch up over high tea.  The little shop across the street has so many wonderful little things, I can never resist picking up some of my favorite teas (Yorkshire Gold or BlackCurrant!).  The service is friendly and warm.  I feel lucky that I am within walking distance.
author: Courtney Y.

description: Who knew you could get such a great buzz from fruity tea or so stuffed-to-the-gills with dainty little sammiches and buttery warm scones?  I love that the atmosphere is way more your auntie's living room than some cold Palace (although the latter is more conducive to tiara-wearing, depending on your auntie).  Added bonus and little-known fact: They hold your reservation for the full HOUR timeslot.  This is great if you're one of those California-time people (or your partner/pals are).
author: Andi T.

description: I am still stuffed and I ate over an hour ago!  The finger sandwiches were very good (as far as English fare goes-note that I am not a big fan of white bread; my favorite was the chicken-apple-walnut), the scones light, the clotted cream thick and rich, and the tea delicious.  Our high tea for two also came with salad, coleslaw, and shortbread cookies. Beautifully presented, servers are nice and efficient, and we luckily did not have to wait at all without a reservation (reservations are recommended).  A great place to dish with a girlfriend and a fun atmosphere.
author: Yodel A.

description: Such a wonderful experience! I took my mom and sister here and we all got the Queen's Tea to get the full tea experience. The tables all say "Reserved for Royalty" or "Reserved for Queens" which I thought was very cute. We had a mango tea which was delicious and the food was great too. Our server was very attentive and knowlegable of the teas. On of the owner's, Gillian is such a sweetheart too! She kept coming to our table to check-in and see how everything was. I will definitely be back.
author: Tara M.

description: I love tea and this place makes my love for tea even greater. I love their tea selections and how everything is designed as an actual tea place. Reminds me when I was younger when I used to play tea time with my sisters and friends. Now I can come here with my sisters and friends when we're adults and still love it. Great experience, great tea sandwiches, and great tea selections.
author: Carissa E.

description:
if you want a unique way to spend time with your sister, mother, grandma, best girlfriend, this is the way to do it. 

lovejoy is tea at its girliest and its so fun. the room is covered in antique florals and lace and well, the place makes you want to bust out in some sort of british accent.

my favorites here are:
-cucumber and cream cheese sandwich
-chicken apple walnut sandwich
-scones with double devon cream

dont be fooled, the sandwiches are finger-sandwiches but they will fill you up fast! 

tip: sometimes they sell old teacups for a couple bucks each. it makes for a great party favor, or a souvenir for yourself. also - lovejoys is located close to some sweet shops. to complete the girly day, plan for some post-afternoon tea shopping :)
author: Jessica C.

description: What is with every tea place in SF rationing scones as if they are made of gold?  Argh.  This decor is cute, the tea and bites were tasty, and the service was fine, but the scarcity was really annoying.  We ordered a Queen's Tea -- one of the largest combos they have -- and it came with only ONE scone across the FOUR of us.  Um, last I checked, a $28 tea platter should not be intended to be eaten by one single person.  So we had to order the Cream Tea in order to get additional scones.  When our platters were served, we were told, "at the end, you'll get a selection of petit fours."  Okay, cool - that sounds fun and yummy.  Fast forward about an hour.  The "selection" showed up...a cute, colorful variety of teeny tiny cake bites...and we were allowed to choose ONE.  For all four of us.  Is sugar and dough really THAT expensive???  What the heck?!  It's basically the same deal at the Secret Garden tea place.  I love the tea tradition, but I am really baffled and annoyed by the stingy servings, especially given that people generally go to tea in groups.  Plural.  Sheesh.
author: Molly P.

description:
Ok, very weird... I just went on here to revise my original review, and add this:

I just had to add to my lovejoys experience... couple weeks ago, my friend n had her babyshower here. The same woman who greeted us when we came the first time was there again. She was super friendly. We had two tables at the back of the restaurant for two hours. For parties, you just decide on the tea service and which sandwiches, and they serve it family style to the tables. If you go over the two hours there is a fee, so no time for games (yay I was NOT looking forward to baby games) but we opened presents and had a great time. The food was yummy. At the end, n got to take the extra food home, they boxed it up for her. Our hostess got the whole group together outside for a photo and took 2 pics from everyone's camera who had one (which was quite a few!).  Great service and a fun afternoon!

When I couldn't find my original review. I was so sure I wrote one... maybe I didn't... or maybe it dissapeared... strange... so to memorialize my original visit a year ago, here's an excerpt from a blog I wrote at the time, a yr ago when my parents visited from nh:

Friday, I took the day off from work, and nelly and jade had the day off too. So the five of us went to tea. Not just any old tea, but special girly frilly tea. I always knew I'd take my parents to lovejoys tea house, should they ever visit. Especially my mother would like it. Months earlier, when I found out they were coming, I bought a dress just for the tea place. I even bought shoes to match the dress later, for tea. LOL I figure, you're gonna have real tea, might as well do it right. So, dressed in my cute new green dress, we went to tea. We were actually EARLY for once, and jade was late, as usual, but our earliness made her seem later. That place is GIRLY. We sat on sofas with crocheted things, there were flowers and doilies and frills everywhere. Daddy was a bit uncomfortable to be a guy in that place. There was always one other guy there, plus a guy waiter, but still. I don't think that place could have gotten more feminine. Especially when a lady with a baby showed up and nelly and jade ran over to fawn over and play with it. We got the full tea and it was really good. The food was kinda small, but I ended up full, for an hr or so. I loved the bathroom, the mirror in there was really pretty. My mother went overboard with picture taking at tea. Every bite was a picture... We all had fun though...
author: Merredith L.

description: Love place... every nice people but i guess they have a no cell phone policy..
author: V b.

description: Make a reservation and prepare to put on your pretty pearls! I actually crave their scones, cucumber and cream cheese sandwiches, and chicken apple walnut sandwiches.  I would avoid the coleslaw, my friends and I were so hungry last time we forgot it tastes "garbagey!" and after the first (and last) forkful we spent a couple minutes trying to drown out the flavor with our bottomless blood orange tea! :)  Take a trip to the attic across the street if you have time!
author: Valerie A.

description: The black English-style tea was very good of course (mixed with milk as the Limeys do) but the tea sandwiches, scones and cookies really impressed. Especially the clotted cream-I can still taste it-Yum! The decor is as frilly-tea-party as you can get, complete with guests dressed up in bonnets and white gloves. One gent out with the ladies even sported a Napoleon outfit. So there you go.
author: Brandon R.

description: I cant believe that I haven't yelped lovejoys yet!  This is by far one of my favorite places in the city to go to.  Its basically a very casual british tea room.  Everything is miss-matched and the place has a very cozy feel.  The owner is so nice, she even remembers me by name (I used to go here at least once a month in the few years following the discovery).  If its your first time here I suggest getting the queens tea and splurging a little... after that you will know what your favorite things are and could get a smaller service  if you like (or not).  IF you go here a lot (like I do) try something different with the ploughmans lunch (an assortment of cheeses and chutney and bread, etc.).  Lovejoys is perfect for small parties or gathering but they book up fast so make reservations as far in advance as possible.  They usually keep a few walk in seats available but if you are walking in get there right before opening or you might miss your chance!
author: Evan O.

description: A reservation is a really good idea- while we were there the wait for a table was over an hour.  Of course we had a reservation- we went for my birthday. The food was delicious, the people were sweet and the decor kept me busy for almost an hour.  PLus, we were stuffed. Perfect for lunch or late brunch on the weekend. I can't wait to go back again.  No pearls necessary.
author: Jordan M.

description:
I can't say enough good things about this place.  You really feel like you've stepped into a tea house in Britain when you go there.  They have a really large selection of both teas and sandwiches and I've always really enjoyed all the food and teas I've tried here.  

I've visited Lovejoys a couple of times wtih only one other person, and they were able to fit us in at the last minute, but the place is usually crowded so if you want to definitely get a table, you need to make reservations in advance. And, if you have a larger party, you need to book a few weeks out because this place is so popular.

In addition to all of the lovely English decorations, one nice thing is that while some parties are dressed up for special occassion, you don't feel uncomfortable in casual clothing or jeans.  It is a great place to take your Mom, to go with your girlfriends or for a young girl's tea party.

And, they make a great "high tea" with clotted cream and fresh scones.
author: Travel G.

description: Awesome place for high tea!  It is so cute and cozy, with all sorts of tastefully mismatched teacups.  The Queen Tea is a good value -- it may not seem it from the description, but it truly is filling, even for a gargantuan glutton like me.  I especially love the cheese & chutney sandwiches, and service is excellent. Make reservations.
author: Leena K.

description: When you're feeling especially 'girly' - this is a great place to meet your female friends.  I went on a recently hot day - too hot for tea - but ordered the Ginger Beer (like root beer but made of ginger - YUM!)  The mini sandwiches and scones were also a nice little mid-afternoon snack to get me through to dinner.
author: Kristin S.

description: Fun experience! Yummy little sandwiches, made me think of old English ladies and their tea time... hope I'm that lucky to have high tea one day when I'm old and gray!
author: Judi K.

description: Just went to lovejoy's tea room for mother's day brunch (3 people total) but it wasnt all that great.. it was $29/per person for tea, 2 types of sandwiches that you can choose from a list, scone, fruit, salad, shortbread cookie, etc... its certainly not worth about $80 (with tax) for 3 people for the food which isnt that good.. the tea is ok but i've had better and the atmosphere is small and the seats werent that comfortable to sit in either.. the palace hotel afternoon tea is about the same price or a bit higher but the food and atmosphere is much better there (in my opinion).. lovejoy's tea room was not worth the hype for me at least..
author: Elina A.

description: I have a date for high tea with the ladies at Lovejoy's, and I'm searching for something appropriately girly to wear. Sipping large amounts of tea from fancy little cups while inhaling creamy (yummy chicken apple walnut) sandwiches requires a somewhat floral and preferably roomy dress. I'm really looking forward to it.
author: Jayme M.

description: I love this place.  From the food to the service to the decor.  They have tiny delicious tea sandwiches to go with your tea.  It's a great place to go with your girlfriends and afterwards you can browse their store across the street!
author: Shum S.

description: I felt like Alice in Wonderland!  This place is so cute.  They have a nice assortment of teas and options to nibble on.  Although I doubted the freshness of a finger sandwich or two, I still left very full.  It's a great place to catch up with friends.  They're not pretentious nor do they try to oust you out after you finished your dessert.  You definitely need to make reservations as they have a limited number of tables.
author: Ready To Be S.

description: A group of us came to Lovejoy for high tea and my bridal shower.  This place is so quaint, cozy, and in a word, delightful. The service was excellent and our server was happy to make tea recommendations for us. I fell in love with the China Rose Petal tea. It was perfect and light and didn't require any sugar or cream. I tried the Vanilla tea, and immediately went back to the rose petal tea. Yum!  I had the warm scone with strawberry jam - it was yummy. We also had a variety of finger sandwiches: chicken curry, shrimp, smoked salmon, cucumber, turkey and dijon.  This place was a great way to spend a nice mellow afternoon.
author: Annie Y.

description: Doily-covered sofas, crumpets with cream, mismatched antique china, and hostesses in frilly aprons...a perfect setting for bridal & baby showers, or an afternoon with the girls.  Boys, beware; there's enough estrogen in this room to widen your hips....(or is that from the cookies?)...but the brave are rewarded with sandwiches of fig & olive tapenade, and steaming scones with jam.
author: Alison C.

description: umm.....so this is pretty much the cutest place ever. You go in and everything is mismatched in the most wonderfully perfect way. They have an awesome selection of tea and tea snacks. Perfect for a leisurely afternoon, bridal/baby showers, or if you just really like tea. The atmosphere is relaxed, cozy and comfy.
author: Morgan E.

description: I love Lovejoy's.  I've been coming here for several years now for an occasional tea time and for special events.  I just hosted a baby shower there and they were so helpful in the planning.  Our waitress was really efficient and friendly.  The food there is always good and the teas are unique.  Nothing beats the atmosphere though.  It's so quaint and relaxing.  It feels like home.  I only wish I could spend hours and hours there sipping tea and chatting with friends.  But alas one must vacate in two hours which is totally understandable because it's such a popular place!
author: Julie D.

description: This place is so precious! I love trying new things! My friends and I came here for a gf's birthday! We ordered high tea which came with teas, scones, crumpets, sandwiches, cookies, and more! It was a tower of food! OH, they also had fruits as well. Their teas were delicous, some teas had very strong aromas, some are just right, and my silly me just ordered green tea! It tasted just like any other green teas, but the other teas that I tasted were good! You have to make reservations because they book up and they close early, too. Great place to take your lovely mothers, grandmothers, and of course with your girlfriends, maybe a gay friend, and boys are very limited here!
author: Jojo N.

description:
It's really all about the ritual of afternoon tea for me. If all the elements are there, I'm pretty much sold. This might make me seem indiscriminate, but I like to think of my attitude towards afternoon teas as, um, collaborative. It exists, knowing that I will consume. 
My parents came  from Sac the weekend of 1/13/2007 to take me to the place of my choice for my birthday. I had tried to get a reservation for Saturday on Thursday, but it was booked through the weekend, so I was put on a waitlist. Friday afternoon I got a phone call from Gillian at Lovejoy's telling me that there'd been a cancellation and would I like to come the next afternoon? God, yes! I had never been before, but an old friend had recommended it repeatedly, based on our mutual love of Jane Austen. 
After driving around Noe Valley with my father cursing about how much he hates the city and its parking/traffic situation, we arrived intact and were promptly seated...although at one of the lame tables that didn't include a cushy seat or couch. I mean, it was fine, just not special. My parents are super cheap and, while I had wanted to get the Queen's Tea (which included petit fors), my mother suggested that I get the (less expensive) High Tea. For my birthday. Sigh.... My parents jumped on board and we ended up ordering High Tea for three, with an endless pot of apricot flavored black tea. The tea was smooth, not overly caffeinated, and super drinkable -- to the extent that two different servers remarked on how much we were going through. 
When the food came (very quickly...almost suspiciously so), it was on a three-tiered tea tray, as it should be. We had mismatched sets on a lacy tablecloth with a charming clutter in the background that soothed (rather than angered) my aesthetic sensibilities. A good thing, since the sandwiches were sort of disappointing. They weren't terrible, but the roast beef with horseradish was almost undetectable between the two layers of de-crusted wonder bread. The egg salad was good and more like what I had expected, while the pear and stilton was skimpy as well...to the point of the strong cheese's flavor being almost indistinguishable. The scone, on the other hand was grand, and came with (one of the key elements to a tea!) clotted Devonshire cream and preserves. The shortbread -- something I am usually not that big a fan of -- was also very good, as was another surprise winner, the caraway seeded coleslaw (I usually avoid slaw as something that too often seems like a mere conduit for mayonnaise)! The greens with some kind of citrusy vinaigrette were also tasty and fresh. 
At the end of the meal, a waitress came around with a tray of petit fors, and Mommy asked if I wanted one. I said I wasn't sure (always afraid to test the cheapness waters) and she said she was getting one, so I might as well...Queen's tea after all! I got the triple chocolate cake one, which tasted like it sounded: heavy and chocolatey; and Mommy got a Victorian wedding cake fors, which was very vanilla and very good -- shockingly good for white cake!
My parents didn't say too much about what they thought...we have such different tastes that I think they were waiting to see what I thought before they said something conflicting (silly, but appreciated!). I liked all the girls who worked there...they were friendly and accommodating. Unfortunately for them, Dad's caffeine caught up with him in a desperate way which resulted in a lengthy bathroom visit. 
On the whole, I felt sufficiently able to pretend I was a gentleman's daughter (no help from actual Dad here) in 19th century England and, hence, will be back with the utmost dispatch.
author: Aimee F.

description: Funky, funky old grandmother's mismatched home furnishings and serving pieces. Kind of a place to experience crustless sandwiches, scones and English tea. It has its share of fans. I would prefer the Ritz Carleton.
author: miriam b.

description: I've been going here for almost 10 years now. I had my 15th birthday party there, now I'm 23, and I'm still loving it. I really enjoy the freshly baked scones with devonshire cream and preserves (MMM). I'm always satisfied when I walk out, especially with the tea and sandwiches. I'm never overly stuffed and my stomach never feels like it's gonna burst. It's a great place to hang out and just enjoy tea!!
author: Cristina D.

description: Been here several times before and the service and food is always good.  My girlfriends and I usually order the High Tea.  The finger sandwiches are delicious and so are the fresh scones w/the clotted cream. Our faves are the smoked salmon, chicken asparagus, egg, and bay shrimp sandwiches.  Stay away from the roast beef -- they can be a bit dry.
author: Tina T.

description: If you want a really authentic and delicious high tea, head to Lovejoy's.  It's cozy and adorable and the staff really knows their stuff.  Be sure to ask them to reccommend their favorite teas.  Reservations are a must.
author: Kaitlin V.

description:
Personally, I was just not impressed by this place at all...maybe because I lived in London for a few years :)

1) It's strange to serve fruits as part of the tea, and it's even more strange to serve coleslaw and greens with sandwiches. I have been to enough tea in London to know how it's supposed to be.

2) The food and its presentation are not and do not look delicate. They don't taste that great either.

3) To me, the most important part of the tea is the scone. This is how you can tell whether or not a place serves good tea. And the scone here is really just ok.

Final verdict: I mean this place is not terrible. I just don't think I will go back.
author: Elin K.

description: I LOVE TEA and I also love cute dainty sandwiches and pastries to go with it!!! This is my favorite tea house that I've tried so far. I love the mismatched china, the cute table cloths, and the kawaii interior. It's not a very big tea place but it's fun to go with a few girlfriends. The food is also really good. The portions don't look very big but it is enough to fill you up fast. I love having the High Tea with friends. The Queen's tea might be a little too much food. I can't wait until my next tea date with friends.
author: Lisa M.

description: Haven't been here in years, but I used to LOVE this place!  It's time to revisit!!
author: Ladi Da A.

description:
This place made me miss my Grannie. She was a buttery old Scottish lady who introduced me at a tender age to the delights of afternoon tea. Sitting on a puffy little tuffet, daintily munching on crustless lil' sandwiches stuffed with cream cheese, cucumbers, watercress, and other assorted goodies. Slathering crispy, delicate scones with fluffy Devon cream and lemon curd. And getting totally cracked-out on sugary  Darjeeling tea while learning how to conduct myself in a mannerly fashion. 
At Lovejoy's, I enjoyed all of the above, minus the watercress and mannerly fashion, but plus the following: cheddar and chutney sandwiches, delicious coleslaw (really it was exceptional - how many people can say that about coleslaw?), ripe melon and berries, shortbread, crumpets, and petit fours. I think at some point I emitted a very lady-like "Oink."
All-in-all, a very civilized afternoon. Just don't go here if you have an irrational fear of doilies.
author: Delilah P.

description: Going to this place is like going to have tea at my great-grandma's house. Its just too cute for words.  There are mismatched doilies, teacups and saucers.  I've brought my friends here for high tea and girl talk.  Their rooibos vanilla is my fave and they have such a variety of sandwiches that I always try something different each time.  Their sweets are too sweet for me so I tend to refrain. But overall, this place is somewhere I will always be coming back to with the girls!
author: Grace V.

description: So fun! We went here for a friend's bridal shower. The ambiance was very charming and sweet. I felt like my inner child who would play make-believe tea party had her dreams come true! The different teas were tasty and the sandwhiches and scones were yum! I'm inspired to create the same experience at home. But it won't be the same as I dont have the cute tea sets and antique decor. I'd definitely throw an intimate shower here in the future!
author: Maureen D.

description: My bridesmaid hosted my bridal shower here! It was such a great experience and something new that we've never done before.  The decor was very antique and felt like we were in another era!  The tea, tea sandwiches and scones were delicious and we just loved everything about the place!  I can't wait to go back for more and dress up in our "Sunday Best".  :)
author: Valerie C.

description: Spent Saturday afternoon at Lovejoys with two wonderful friends.  The tea was fantastic - Chestnut and Rooibos.  The food was excellent - we had the Shepperd's Pie, which was very tasty.  We also had the Sausage wrapped with Puff Pastry - can't go wrong with that.  My favorite sandwich was the roastbeef & horseradish but I also enjoyed the turkey/dijon, green apple/cream cheese and cucumber/cream cheese.  The shortbread cookies and scones with devonshire cream topped it all off.  We had an excellent server and as always when coming to Lovejoys, the owner's were very friendly and welcoming.  Thanks for keeping this place top notch!
author: Cristina M.

description: It is my dream to wake up and be British. Naturally, I heart Lovejoy's. Despite this dream, I am not the hugest tea fan, but their mango and sweet teas are really good. As are the petit fours. Warning: if you are clumsy at all, be wary of Lovejoy's as there are delicate plates and platters and cups aplenty to be knocked over. It's a bit pricey, but it's cheaper than high tea in London!
author: Mairead J.

description: This is most definitely my favorite place to go eat. It's such a treat! The food is delicious, and the teas are great.  I love the ambiance. I highly recommend it!
author: VANESSA R.

description: I LOVE this place. It is a fantastic spot to go with your girlfriends to catch up on life happenings and sip some tea. I would never put my boyfriend through the torture of attending with me though I think he would lust after the Shepard's Pie as much as I do. sadly, it is often unavailable - especially if you don't come early enough - but I still cannot give Lovejoy's any less than 5 stars.
author: Marina G.

description: This place sucks. I felt like I was eating dinner in my grandma's bathroom on acid. It is overpriced and the tea wasn't even that good. They play this really cool trick on you, Samovar does the same thing, called a Tea Service where they charge you almost 20 bucks for two or three tiny plates of food with some tea. The trick is they bring it with a really impressive rack holding these really nice fancy plates. It's all in the presentation and not in the recipe. I'd rather go visit my grandma, it's cheaper.
author: Kyle J.

description: This place should be for special occasions because its so special, but its hard not to go there often for lotsa tea and some yummy sandwiches and crumpets. As a vegetarian there are many options for sandwiches that are deliciousness, their service is great, and atmosphere is fun. I go here with my boyfriend and we enjoy sipping here for a while. We have never made a reservation and have always found the wait not too bad, but would probably make a reservation in the future because you never know. This place is cozy and beloved.
author: Sari G.

description: It's like you are in nightmare where you're stuck having tea with girls at grandma's house.  Okay it isn't that bad.  My lady dragged me and our friends from Chicago over here for breakfast.  They have a really great niche going on here.  Great little sandwiches, Sheppard's pie, and of course their scones!  Does anyone know if they make them themselves or order it from a bakery?  And their 15+ different teas.  I believe most of the decorations are up for sale and they also have a retail store across the street.  Make reservations on the weekends because it was packed!  So if you want to be British for a day, come here at about 12pm.
author: Jason A.

description: This is the place that first taught me to love Tea. I have never felt so girly in all my life. You kind of feel like a giant with doughy hands that could break stuff at any moment. But I'm ok with that. I have been here with friends and by myself (and that says alot.) Everything has always been delicious. It's a little pricey so it's a fun splurge. Come to think of it, this is also the place that keeps me addicted to Tea.
author: Maya S.

description:
Can't give it a 5 because it would have to be in London (Basil Street Inn gets 5).  Came here for my birthday on a lovely rainy, wintery day and Lovejoy's was the perfect, cozy setting for a romantic afternoon tea with my husband (who, fortunately, is very secure with his masculinity and did not mind being the only guy in the entire place).  The space is definitely girly with its artful clutter of packaged teas, crockery, and various knicknacks.  The tea was delicious and unlimited (though I wonder who can actually go through more than one generous pot of tea).  Tea for Two was perfect--a generous portion of tea sandwiches, two scones, Devonshire cream, and two pots of tea, plus salad and sauerkraut (which I skipped, since it was my b'day and I don't eat veggies on my birthday).  My only complaint would be the scone.  It was nice and warm but tasted a little more biscuit-like than scone-like; I think I detected a note of pre-packaged scone-ness.  Otherwise, this place is a real find and in a great location.  Just a couple blocks up and you're in Noe Valley and can stop by the awesome Noe Knit store (if you're a knitting fanatic as I am) or Ambiance clothing.  Even my husband, a Noe Valley detractor, managed to find a sufficiently obscure LP at Streetlight to add to our growing collection of useless, unplayable LPs.

Anyway, I digress.  Lovejoy's Tea Room.  Try it.  It's absolutely ripping.
author: Samantha R.

description: I love the frilly afternoon tea!  It's such a cute spot. The tea sets never match but it's precious that way. there is a wide array of teas you can choose from.  The sandwiches are delicious and the crumpets to die for! It may not sound filling - but make sure your appetites are in tact because you shouldn't underestimate how filling everything is!
author: Anne M.

description: I had a sudden craving for High Tea.. and as we were hanging out in the area, we searched on mobile Yelp on our cellphone and found this place.. it was truly a great hangout for some good food and tea. I went with my husband but we both agreed that this is more of a place for girlfriends and women. I am going back, with my network of girlfriends shortly..yummy scones, sandwiches, shortcake and smooth tea just the way i like it.  As I was saying, this is much better than a typical 5 star hotel that "try" to serve high tea.. Lovejoy's Tea Room is more authentic and laid back.
author: Ada W.

description: I came here on a Sunday with reservations made ahead. It's a nice lovely tea room located in the Noe Valley. Since I have never been to a British Tea room or party, it was definitely a new experience. Their chairs and tables were so cute. They had tables with reserved signs that said, "Reserved for Royalty" or "Reserved for Queens" it was adorable! Their menu was straight forward and a bit pricey. I loved the fact that the tea was bottomless and that the china was mix-matched. The service here is great and they are very attentive. Their scones are so light and fluffy. The clotted cream was soo tasty! My mouth is still watering. Definitely would love to come back soon. Decor is awesome, furniture is neat, china is unique, and great service! Definitely a San Francisco gem!  Bring some of your girlfriends and boyfriends and have a tea party, it's fun :]
author: Rebecca T.

description: Excellent tea room if you enjoy the alternative to let's say the Ritz-Carlton or Fairmont. Don't mind if the tea cups on your table are not  matched with your plates? This is the place to go. It's funky in decor and quite the experience if you are into tea. This is a great place to take your boyfriend to. It's an over the top place to take your girlfriends or to host an event. You can take your mother and I guarantee she'll love it. The food is very good and I've had nothing but great service here. It's an experience in tea that is worth making a reservation a good week in advance for.
author: Teresa C.

description: I hosted a baby shower for 16 people at Lovejoys and it was a perfect location. The staff was very courteous and attentive, the food fun, and the setting relaxing and eclectic. I highly recommend Lovejoy's Tea Room.
author: K Z.

description: The waitress was very nice and accommodating.  With it's funky decor and generous amounts of delicious food and tea, it's my new favourite tea room.
author: Cece W.

description: My friend introduced me to Lovejoy's a few years ago, and I've been a fan since. It's a cute space that filled with all sorts of attic knick-knacks, antique tables and chairs, and cute mix match tea wear, but it all works and it all looks lovely. Love love love, the warm scores, with the devon cream and jam. The sandwiches are cute and good too. My favorites are chicken apple walnut, and the smoked salmon. Great place for birthdays or bridal/baby showers with the girls. If you're looking for something hardier, try the shepherd's pie. It's another favorite of mine.
author: Doris C.

description: I've never had had real high tea until I came to this place! I've heard all the stories of the Ritz and all these other grand tea rooms, but Lovejoy's is just the place for me.  Scones are excellent and the tea is great!  I took my fiance and Mom and we had a great time!  It may not be the most manly thing to go and have tea with the ladies but if ya gotta do it this is the place you gotta go to.
author: Kale T.

description: I love, love, love, their scones!! This a great place for girlfriend get togethers, baby showers, birthdays, and Mother's Day. The first time I went here was with my sister and our mother for her birthday (?) or was it Mother's Day (?). In any case, I fell in love with this place. Been here several times since then. The last time was for my friend's small baby shower. There were six of us and had a great time. I also took my childhood friend for her birthday here. She loved it too. My friends and I all loved the scones. After our tea party, we went across the street to their  little shop where they sell their loose tea, tea accessories, and other items to complete your own little tea party. If only they sold the recipe for their scones =).
author: Neni E.

description: Cozy English tea room with chintzey sofas and antiques.  Perfect for a rainy day.  Just make sure you have a reservation.
author: Michelle M.

description: I really enjoyed Lovejoys's Tea Room... Yummy tea sandwiches and scones, great tea selection, relaxed and homey atmosphere. The service was fast and friendly. They say reservations are recommended, but we walked in and were seated right away. It was really packed (Saturday afternoon - it figures) so I guess we were lucky.
author: Flora B.

description:
My sister-in-law wanted to do English Afternoon Tea Party for my baby shower, so she took me here to taste some tea, scones, and sandwiches.  The place doesn't look much when you go in--at least I didn't think so--, but after you are seated, you'll find that every seats have very cute decor. The tables are covered with some old style table cloth, plate & cup sets are all very pretty, and there are different paintings, pictures, and other decorations all over the store and around the walls.  

We had High Tea for Two, which includes a pot of tea of your choice, 4 choices of sandwiches, 2 scones, and 2 shortbread cookies. I had Vanilla something tea, which is herbal tea, and my sister-in-law added another pot of tea that was caffeinated. The tea was really good, great aroma, and the sandwiches were good too. There was a long list of sandwiches, and we chose chicken asparagus, chicken hummus walnut, figs & olives, and beef and something (I forget). But of course, they are just sandwiches that you can make yourself.  Now the scones... mmm... so good! Very filling, but very good. They give you jam and butter for the scone, but the butter is very different. It's either home-made or flavored butter so it's so very delicious.  It's probably very fattening, but why would I care? I'm having a baby! We were so stuffed before we could finish everything, it cost us a total of $40 including tax & tips. The service was very nice too, so the overall experience was great!

Right across from the tea room, there's its shop where you can get the tea and the tea sets. It's also a very cute store.

We went on a Wednesday for lunch, and we thought it would be less crowded, but it was surprisingly full.
